1.content:
Hi, I'm Staci Parks, and this is my story. Well, our story, since it's about my friends, too. In fact, if we hadn't been such close friends, I don't think it would have happened to us.

See, the six of us had grown up together in the same apartment complex, and we liked to do just about everything together. If you saw two or more of us together, it was usually a safe bet that all six of us were there. But we were in senior year, and college choices just might have split us up.

For myself, the future was FIT. For the layperson, that's the Fashion Institute of Technology. If you didn't learn fashion in Paris or Milan, you damn well better have FIT on your resume. For me, it was nothing less than holy ground.

My boyfriend, Jesse Larson, made it to UConn on a football scholarship. Not prohibitively far, but who's to say what even that distance might have done to the thing we called us?

Dave Forrester was going to Harvard. It was Step One of his career journey, and he saw himself changing the political system, even if Taylor Brown warned him that the system was going to change him.

Speaking of Taylor, she had been accepted by ICE, or the Institute for Culinary Education. It would have worked out great if it had been the New York ICE, but, unfortunately, she had to take the Los Angeles campus.

Tommy Brown, Taylor's twin brother, was going to study music at Berklee. Yes, that's how it's spelled. Studying music was the obvious choice for him, given the guitar that he never liked to be far from.

This left Quinn. She had a last name, but none of us ever used it, her least of all. Quinn was going to put on a good pair of walking shoes, pick up a good stick, and walk wherever the road took her. Seriously, that was what she was going to do, no "until I get into college" or anything.

So, those were our plans.

And, looking back, I'm reminded of something Woody Allen said once: If you want to make God laugh, tell Him about your plans.

******************************


To commemorate what looked like the last time we would all be together, we decided to go camping, instead of going on the senior class trip.

It was Saturday, and we'd driven to the campground, set up our tents, and had supper. As the sun set, we were content to while away the evening with s'mores and songs around the campfire. Tommy, of course, brought his trusty guitar.

I don't remember what song we were singing when it happened, or if it was the fourth or fifth song of the evening. I just remember being distracted by this weird noise. It didn't belong in the forest, and it was getting louder.

"Hey, does anybody - "

Then everything went green.

Then everything went black.

******************************


When we came to, we were each a good 10-15 feet away from the campfire. The fire was out, and there was a mass in its place.

We checked ourselves for any injuries, and found nothing. That's when we noticed it.

"Hey, does anyone else feel - "

"Tingly?"

"Yeah."

It doesn't matter who said what about the tingling sensation, because we all felt it.

That was enough for us. We loaded everything back into the cars, and headed back home.

"What do you think that thing was?" Jesse asked me.

"Don't know, don't care," I replied.

That attitude would change.
1.title: How It Began

11.content:
I must be losing weight, I thought. But where?

Over the last couple of days, I'd noticed that my clothes felt looser. This morning, even my bra and panties seemed too big for me. But, as I checked myself out in my full-length mirror, I couldn't see anything different. Naked, I didn't look the least bit thinner. So why didn't anything fit anymore?

Allie, my stepmother, knocked on my door. "Staci, honey, breakfast is ready."

I put on my bathrobe and opened the door, to tell her to set up a doctor's appointment for me. Maybe Dr. Kumar could figure out why I was losing weight. That's when I saw it.

See, I had stood at 5' 8", since my last growth spurt. Allie, by contrast, wasn't an inch over 5' 5".

So, when I opened the door and saw Allie standing there, the last thing I should have been doing was looking her straight in the eye. Which is what I was doing right then.

Allie noticed it, too. "Staci?"

"Later," I said. "Go take care of Libby. I'll talk about it later."

I closed the door, and called Jesse. He picked up on the second ring. "Hello?" He sounded a little off, but I was too freaked out by my situation for it to register just yet.

"Jesse, something weird happened. You're going to think I'm crazy, but I swear to God, I'm - "

"Smaller?"

"Yeah. Three inches. How'd you know?"

"It happened to me, too."

Both of us? "You call Dave," I said, "I'll call Quinn."

As soon as I got off the line with Jesse, I called Quinn. "Staci," she said, "this has got to be a nightmare, but I can't wake up. Please wake me up."

"If you found yourself shorter," I said, "it's no dream. It's happened to me and Jesse, too. He's calling Dave right now."

"Okay. I'll call Taylor and Tommy."

I hung up, and the phone rang. It was Jesse. "Dave, too."

"Same with Quinn. She's calling Taylor and Tommy."

Quinn called back, confirming that it had happened to Taylor and Tommy, too. That made it unanimous. I cinched up my done (which, I now noticed, was now touching the floor) and went to the kitchen.

All eyes were on me. Allie had clearly told them about me. Not that I blamed her, or even that I didn't want her to. It saved me time.

I sat down. "It's not just me," I said. "All six of us have shrunk."

"What could cause something like this?" Dad asked.

I had only one clue.
11.title: Three Days Later

choices: Waking up in the ambulance as we arrived.
111.content:
Despite how crazy it would sound, I had to make a report of what had happened to the local police department, so whatever was happening to us does not affect anyone else. I reported the incident to the dispatcher, who patiently listened. When I heard her sigh, I expected to be given a lecture about making prank calls, but instead, she calmly replied, "Miss Parks, you are the fifth person to make this report, with identical details of this incident. We have sent a HAZMAT team to the site, and found the object in question."

Gulping, I asked, "Did they find anything to corroborate our claim?"

"The HAZMAT team found a full grown bear the size of a kitten." To my shock, the dispatcher said. "Anyone or anything unprotected from this thing will shrink." She paused, then asked, "Do you remember how long your were unconscious?"

"Hours..." Horrified, I said. "We need help."

"Remain calm, Miss Parks." Firmly but kindly, the dispatcher said. "An ambulance is on its way to you now. I suggest you contact everyone you had been in close proximity to in the last twenty-four hours, to have them checked out as well."

I gulped a second time, my hands trembling. "I'll get ready." My voice quavering, I said. "I have only been in contact with my father, my stepmother, and my sister."

"I will send a separate ambulance for them." Serious, the dispatcher said. "Tell them to get ready, as they, too, may have been exposed to this radiation through you..."

Now I was terrified. "Radiation?..."

After ending the call, I turned to Allie, shaking. "They're sending two ambulances, one for me, and one for you guys and Libby." Tearfully, I explained. "It turns out we were all exposed to some form of radiation, and that is what's causing this."

"Radiation is cumulative." Worried, Allie said. "I'll grab Libby, and see if I can find something for you to wear."

She ran off to Libby's room and presently returned with a bra and panty set, as well as a skirt and blouse set that looked to be more in my size. "Where on Earth did you find these?" Surprised, I asked.

Allie blushed slightly. "I tend to keep at least two outfits as you grow out of them, for memories." Softly, she admitted. "We all have our own little obsessions..."

I did not comment on that, as I was grateful I had something to wear that fit. While I quickly got dressed, Dad and Allie rushed to gather what they thought we may all need for a lengthy hospital stay. The two ambulances arrived shortly after, with paramedics in Hazmat suits who quickly, but gently, put us on gurneys and rolled us into the ambulances. Allie carried Libby, who was crying at this point, frightened by all the strange clothed people all around her. I had to admit, I was crying in fear as well, at that point.

"Try to remain calm, Miss Parks." politely, one paramedic said. "You are in good hands."

"I- I'm scared..." Crying, I admitted. "Am I going to die?"

"Not if we can help it." Serious, the paramedic replied. "Just relax and let us take care of you."

I don't remember much about the ride to the hospital, as I felt a prick in my arm just before I fell into darkness...
111.title: Making the Report

1111.content:
When I woke up, I was in a hospital bed, in a gown. And I wasn't alone in the room. "Jesse!" I got up and hugged him, not remembering until he was in my arms that my gown opened in the back.

I went to hold it closed, but Taylor's voice said, "That's a bit like closing the barn door after the horses got out."

I turned. The rest of our group was there, as well.

"Don't sweat it, Staci," Tommy said. "What happens in quarantine, stays in quarantine."

Relaxing, I put my mind on other things. "Which one of you was the first to call the police?"

Dave raised his hand. "I can be very persuasive, and this situation called for that."

"Don't let him fool you, Staci," Jesse said. "He was freaking out as much as anybody when I called him."

The door to the containment room opened, and a figure in a hazmat suit entered. A figure with a familiar face. "How are you, Staci?"

"Smaller, and scared, Dr. Kumar," I replied. "How are the folks and Libby?"

"They're doing well. Libby's playing with the other children. I think she'll come out of here with new friends."

"How about us?" Dave asked. "Any word on what we're dealing with?"

"Not the last I heard, young man." Turning to me, she said, "Allie sent me to reassure you. She knew you'd be more worried about them." With that, she left.

Now that I knew my family was okay, I turned my attention back to the group. Spotting Quinn sitting alone, I decided to sit next to her. "You've been quiet," I said. "Any reason?"

"Just wondering," she replied. "How do you suppose that bear is doing?"

I chuckled. Classic Quinn. "Nice to know that part of you is undiminished."

Another doctor came in. Seeing this, Dave asked, "Can you tell us what we're dealing with? What is that thing?"

"As a matter of fact," the doctor said, "we can pass along further information. What you found was... "
1111.title: Waking up in the hospital.

11111.content:
"... a meteorite."

"Do they know how to reverse this?" Dave asked.

"Not yet," the doctor replied. "Remember, we just found it this morning. We have plenty of work to do."

"What happens now?" I asked.

"Now, we continue to monitor you and your families, to see if you continue to shrink and if they begin to shrink."

"How... How small do you think we'll get?" Dave asked.

"Well," Quinn said, "there's a bear the size of a kitten. We can extrapolate from that."

They measured us. We were the same size we were that morning. Then, they went to measure our families.

We sat in silence for a while, until Jesse asked me, "What's your mom up to?"

"I don't know," I replied, "I only get updates in letters on my birthday." When my parents divorced, my mom embarked on what she calls a "journey of self-discovery." Last year, she was in India. In my darker moments, usually when I had trouble making a design work, it would occur to me that the only things my mom had discovered about herself were that she didn't want to be married or have a daughter.

Jesse put his arm around me. "We'll be okay," he said, as if sensing my thoughts right then. "You'll see."

"And if we shrink smaller than that bear?" Dave asked. "What then?"

I swear, I could almost hear the others glaring at Dave. "Then we'll be okay tiny people," Taylor half-shouted.
11111.title: A Meteorite

111111.content:
I had nightmares all night, about being smaller than everyone, and trying to avoid being stepped on or eaten by strays. Thanks a bunch, Dave.

My mood wasn't helped by the morning's examinations, which showed that I'd shrunk to 5'4", and the others had shrunk as well. "How are our families?" Jesse asked.

"There's been no change," the doctors said. "We'll continue to monitor them, just in case." With that, they left.

"Well, that's some good news," Taylor said. "I'd hate myself if I wound up doing this to Cameron." Cameron was the twins' younger brother, set to start high school in the fall.

Orderlies in hazmat suits wheeled in a surprise for us: a big screen TV. They plugged it in, and we could watch almost whatever we wanted.

It was almost enough to take our minds off the fact that we were shrinking. The fact that the story had made the news certainly didn't help. "Who told them?" I asked.

"It could have been anybody," Tommy said. "The whole building knew we were all picked up by ambulances, Cameron had no reason not to tell anyone about our camping trip, and I'm sure the shrunken bear made the news. Who wouldn't connect the dots?"
111111.title: The Next Morning

1111111.content:
It was shortly before we were normally served lunch when a nurse in a hazmat suit entered with a DVD. "We just got this in a few minutes ago, from the US Fish and Wildlife Service." Calmly, she said. "We figured you would want to know what had happened at the campsite, and what had happened to the bear."

She loaded the DVD and we watched the video. We were all shocked to find the entire campsite powdered with a fine layer of sand-colored dust. I had not thought of it before, but we were all covered in the dust when we woke up. I figured it was from the impact of the meteorite.

The the video switched to a tiny bear in a glass cage, growling but feasting of pieces of fish. We all cooed and chuckled at the sight of the little bear standing on its back paws, showing her authority to the veterinarians working on treating her.

"I think we should call her Teddie," smiling, Quinn said.

I giggled at that. "I doubt they will let us keep her as a pet, Quinn."

Quinn grinned before motioning to herself. "Stranger things have happened."

"Don't jinx us." Serious, Dave warned. "We've had enough strangeness to last a while."

Quinn shrugged. "I'll rephrase,... a girl can dream."

I could only shake my head. Never change, Quinn. smiling, I thought.

Shortly after the video ended, we were served lunch, which consisted of bananas, rice, applesauce, tea and toast. Seeing it, Jesse sighed. "I'm beginning to see why they call this the BRAT diet." Pouting, he said. "I feel like we're being punished for being sick."

"Radiation poisoning is a serious illness." Calmly, the nurse explained. "Small meals that are light on the stomach are highly recommended."

"Can we see our family sometime soon?" Wincing, Taylor asked.

"They will be allowed to see you, one at a time, later today." Serious, the nurse said. "As their condition has not changed in the past few days, they are being released tomorrow morning."

We all sighed at that, since we were unlikely to see the light of day for a while. Still, I knew that we were all grateful that our condition was not affecting our family. "At least they are safe from this small problem." Trying to be light, Tommy said.

"Did you have to say small, bro?" rolling her eyes, Taylor complained.


About an hour later, the first family member entered the room. It was...
1111111.title: Visitors

11111111.content:
"Daddy!"

I ran up and gave him the biggest hug I could. If it wasn't for the hazmat suit, I'd have given him a kiss, too.

He hugged me right back. "How's my little girl?"

I shushed him. "We're... kind of sensitive about words like that right now."

"Oops, sorry," he said. "How are you, though?"

"Better, now that I can see you. I'm glad you guys are okay."

"I don't think Libby will be okay until you come home. You're all she talks about."

"Well, you can tell her that, as much as she misses me, I miss her ten times more. You've heard the news?"

"You just let me worry about reporters, young lady. Your job is to get better, so you can come home. And remember, they're not allowed in the building without permission, and I'm certainly not about to give it to them."

I breathed a sigh of relief. "You always know how to make me feel better, Daddy."

"And seeing a smile on your face always makes me feel better, Staci."

A nurse came in. "Time's up, Mr. Parks."

Dad gave a heavy sigh. "Love you, Staci."

"Love you, too, Daddy. Give my love to Allie and Libby."

It went like that for all of us. We all felt worlds better for some human contact.
11111111.title: my father.

111111111.content:
Two days later (5'2"), we were about to have lunch, when one of the doctors came in. "I have an important announcement to make," she said, "one which, I think, will make you all very happy."

"You've found the cure for the common shrinking," joked Tommy.

"Not quite that happy, she said. "Tomorrow, you will all be discharged."

To hear the reaction this got, you might have thought we'd all started growing again.

When we settled down, Dave asked, "May I ask why? After all, you haven't got the cure."

"There are two reasons, Mr. Forrester: First, we are confident that none of you represents what we would call a contamination hazard. Exposure to you will not harm anyone." To make her point, she removed her hood. "Second, the fact is that, apart from your shrinking, none of you are ill in any measurable way, and we need this space for sick people. After lunch, telephones will be plugged in next to your beds, and you will get to give your families the good news yourselves."

After that announcement, even another round of the BRAT diet didn't seem so bad. You'd have thought we hadn't had solid food in ages, the way we gobbled it down.

As promised, the orderlies hooked up the phones, and they were as glad to be out of the hazmat suits as we were to have the return home in sight. I took several deep breaths, composing myself and planning what I wanted to say.

Finally, I made the call. Dad picked up. "Hello?"

"Hi, Daddy, it's Staci."

"Staci! God, it's good to hear your voice again."

"Same here, Daddy. I called to tell you two things: First, tell Allie that, tomorrow, I'll be about five foot one. Let me hear you tell her that."

"Alright. Allie, Staci wants me to tell you that she'll be five foot one tomorrow. No, I don't know why, either."

"The second thing, Daddy, is... I'm coming home."

"Home? Really?" I could hear cheering in the background.

"Yup. Clean bill of health. You know, except for the shrinking."

"My baby's coming home," Dad said, and I could hear him trying to hold it together for just a bit longer. "You don't know how happy that makes me."

"Not half as much as it makes me," I replied, fighting back my own tears. "I love you, Daddy."

"I love you, too, pumpkin."

"Well, I'll see you tomorrow. 'Bye, Daddy."

"Goodbye, Staci. See you tomorrow."

With the call over with, I let myself cry, more tears of joy than you might expect from someone my size.

After we were all done calling and crying, we started talking amongst ourselves. "What's gonna be the first thing you do when you get home?" Taylor asked.

"Eat a steak," Jesse said.

"Pet my cats," Quinn said, "if they want to be petted."

"I'm going to hug and kiss my whole family," I said, "and I don't know when I'm going to stop."
111111111.title: The News

1111111111.content:
We were going home. Nothing - not even the morning's examinations, which confirmed my estimate of 5'1" - could dampen our spirits. We cheered the orderlies as they set up curtains to make dressing areas.

I was glad to see Dad and Allie again, and was thrilled to see they'd brought Libby along. "She insisted on coming along," Allie said.

I didn't care whose idea it was. I wanted to pick her up and spin her around, but I couldn't get her up that high. It shouldn't have surprised me: after all, I was only 11 inches taller than her now.

******************************


After a stop at the drive-thru for a non-BRAT lunch, it was back to the apartment building. There were reporters there still (hadn't anything important happened while I was in the hospital?), but Dad was still able to get into the parking garage.

As we ate in the living room, Dad filled me in on what had happened since Tuesday. "Crews came in and cleaned out your room. They left it in a bit of a state, but we put it back together. Had to replace a few things, no big deal."

"I'll look at it later," I said, idly brushing Libby's hair as she lay her head in my lap.

"School wants you kids to attend classes as usual. But they're setting up so you can take your classes online if things get too difficult, you know, what with the reporters and all."

Dad specified the reporters, but I think we all knew what he really meant. Whenever we had to walk any distance, they had to stop and wait for me. It wouldn't be long before I could no longer get to class on time.

But those concerns were for another day. Right now, I wanted to sit on the couch, with Allie's arm around me and Libby's head in my lap. I had five friends who had my back, and I was surrounded by my family. I didn't have to be afraid of anything.

Later, I checked out my room. there were a few signs that something had happened in there, but it was in decent shape now.

I noticed that I had some new things. My hamper was new, probably because my camping clothes had been tossed into it. The lamps were new. My bed was new,... and significantly smaller. But, when I climbed into it, my feet reached almost to the end.

My dresser was now stocked with the things Allie had saved. When my old clothes ran out, there were Libby's things. Bless Allie for being a packrat, I thought.
1111111111.title: Going Home

11111111111.content:
Tuesday morning came, and brought with it the end of spring break. I had gotten into the habit of measuring myself, even though I was shrinking at a steady rate of an inch per day. I brought the tape measure up to the top of my head, then checked what it said: 4'10". I was squarely in the elementary school phase of my wardrobe. Next week, I thought, I'll be down to Libby's size,... until I get even smaller. The only clue to how small I'd get was a bear the size of a kitten.

Allie dropped Libby off at kindergarten, then drove me to school. Once there, I realized that, unlike my body, the media's interest in me and my friends showed no signs of getting any smaller. The moment Allie opened my car door, I had microphones and cameras shoved in my face. They all asked me the same asinine question: What's It like to shrink?

Allie was overwhelmed, but rescue came in the form of some boys, who got between me and the reporters. When I looked up to thank them, I recognized them as members of the football team.

"How'd you like the circus?" Jesse asked.

"I prefer it when I'm not the star attraction," I replied, kissing him. Shrinking was hard to deal with, but at least I wasn't going through it alone.

"Staci?" called Morgan Detweiler. She was one of my best friends outside the group. "Is... is that really you?"

"What's left of me," I said, as we walked to homeroom. "How was the class trip?"

"Oh, you know. Nothing interesting ever happens on one of those things."

"Take it from me, Morgan, you don't want to wish too hard for something interesting to happen."

"Ouch. Staci?"

"Yeah?"

"How do you feel? Like, are you sick? Does it hurt?"

"No, it doesn't. In fact, I feel just the same as when I was your size. If I didn't have to crane my neck, or if people didn't have to slow themselves down for me to keep up, I probably wouldn't notice."

But I was wrong. There was plenty to notice. If not the stares, then the fact that my feet no longer reached the floor when I sat down.
11111111111.title: Back to School

111111111111.content:
Our friends surrounded us as a barrier between us and the reporters when school let out, and we waited for our parents to pick us up. "When are they going to let up?" I asked.

"I don't think they'll be here much longer," Dave said. "But, then, neither will we."

We all knew what he meant. It was a nice idea for us to attend classes like everything was normal, but our books were getting heavier, and the distance between one class and another was getting farther. By next week, we'd probably be taking our classes online.

"Anybody got an idea for getting them out of the picture?" Morgan asked.

"I've got one," Tommy said, "but we'll need to talk to our folks about it."

"I'm all ears," Jesse said.I

"They want to ask us questions," Tommy explained. "Why not give them the opportunity?"

"What," I asked, "just invite them over?"

"Not quite. Have our folks call the stations and say, The shrinking kids will have a press conference, and you'll have one chance to ask your questions. After that, you keep your distance, and we get to go on with our lives."

"Think it'll work?"

"I've got nothing to lose by trying," I said.
111111111111.title: After School

1111111111111.content:
"You want to do what?" Dad asked.

"We want to hold a press conference," I replied, emphasizing the word we.

"Sweetie, I thought you wanted to avoid the attention," Allie said.

"After today, I'm not so sure about that. We avoided the press, and got cameras and microphones in our faces the first chance they got."

Dad looked skeptical, but said nothing.

"It's very simple: You and the other parents let them know that we'll have a press conference. We'll answer their questions, unless they get too personal or too creepy, and then, they agree to give us all some space. Wouldn't you rather not have to drive past reporters every day? A handful of phone calls can change that."

"They were a nuisance at school today," Allie said.

Dad looked me in the eye, which wasn't too hard, since he was sitting and I was standing. "You really think this will work, Staci?"

First rule of negotiating with my dad: When he goes from cute nicknames to your name, it means that, whatever he was unsure about, he's got his bearings now. "We can give it a shot. If they don't do as they agreed, then you can take action to get rid of them."

He stared at a spot above my head (he'd always done that, he just didn't have to look so high up anymore), and nodded. Second rule of negotiating with my dad: When he does that, you've got him in your corner. "We'll see."

About that time, the phone rang. Dad picked it up. "Parks family. Oh, hello, George." George was Jesse's dad. "We were just talking about that."

Long story short, Dad made some calls to the media. The press conference was set for Friday at 8:00 AM.

The next day, there were no reporters in front of the building, or at school.

A day after that, we were officially asked to begin online classes.
1111111111111.title: Discussing a Press Conference

11111111111111.content:
Allie was doing my makeup, since my hands were shaking too badly for even lipstick. "You're going to be fine," she said.

"Easy for you to say," I replied, "you're not going to be talking to a whole complete country."

"This was your idea," Dad said.

"It seemed like a good idea at the time. Now, it occurs to me that I'm a four-and-a-half-foot tall girl, about to be on TV."

"Four feet, seven inches," Allie said. "Never make yourself out to be less than you are."

Among other things, Allie has a quality about her that, somehow, can't help but inspire people. If I could clone her, I'd make millions.

There was a knock on the door. When Dad answered it, it was Jesse and his father. "All set?" Mr. Larson asked.

Dad looked at Allie. "We're good," she said.

"All set," Dad said. "You have any problems?"

"He was throwing up all morning, but his stomach's settled down now."

Dad shrugged. "I suppose a degree of stage fright is to be expected. Let's head down."

We gathered in the lobby. Dad handed me several sheets of paper. "Knock 'em dead, Staci."

When we were all ready, Dad and Mr. Larson opened the doors, and the six of us walked out. I was glad to see that they had set the microphones at our level. "Good morning," I said. "My name is Staci Parks."

"My name is Jesse Larson."

"My name is Dave Forrester."

"My name is Taylor Brown."

"My name is Tommy Brown."

"And my name is Quinn Del Rey, but everyone just calls me Quinn."

"Before we take any questions," I said, "I have a brief statement." I lifted the papers to the microphones and began to read:

"Two weeks ago tomorrow, the six of us decided to go camping in Mystic Pines National Park, rather than go on the senior class trip to Washington, DC. We made this decision because, since our plans for life after graduation would take us in different directions, we wanted to have one last hurrah for our years-long friendship.

"We were celebrating our first night camping, when our campsite was struck by what proved to be a meteorite. The shock wave from the impact knocked us all out. When we came to, we felt a tingling sensation that we couldn't explain. In a panic, we loaded up our things and drove home. We regret not striking our tents, as we should have."

That got a laugh. I made a mental note to thank Dad for suggesting it.

"After a few days, we realized that we had begun to shrink. The shrinking process occurs at a steady, reliable rate, and is causing us no pain or discomfort. As for how small we can expect to become, our only clue is an adult female bear, now about the size of a kitten. It broke Quinn's heart that she couldn't adopt the bear."

Another laugh. Dad didn't suggest that one, it was my idea.

After that, we took questions from the assembled media for a few minutes, then closed the press conference.

Following that, reporters no longer hectored us.
11111111111111.title: The Press Conference

choices: What an adorable little girl you are
Aren't you one of those shrinking children?
111111111111111.content:
A week had passed since the Press Conference, and the day I’d been dreading had finally arrived. I, a 17-year-old girl, was now shorter than my 5-year-old sister. I now stood at 4 feet even, or the average height of a 4-year-old. This got me no small amount of teasing from Libby, and not just because I was wearing clothes from when she was a toddler.

While Dad stayed at home to finish making the apartment livable for me, Allie decided it would be a good idea to get out of the house while I was still able to do so. Had I known what that entailed, I would have insisted on staying home. The first humiliation came when I saw a second car seat had appeared next to Libby’s. Turning to Allie, a mortified look on my face, I said, “You’ve got to be kidding.”

“I’m sorry, honey, but children at your height are supposed to be in booster seats.” After strapping Libby into hers, Allie turned to me and said, “Libby doesn’t have a problem with it; and, honestly, it’s not like you’re going to need one much longer.”

“But I’m a 17-year-old girl!” frustrated, I said, “I have my driver’s license; now you expect me to sit in a child’s car seat?”

“This is the only way we’ll be able to go to the mall.” Lifting me into the car, Allie said, “I’m not about to get a ticket because you were being stubborn.”

I realized there was nothing I could do to fight this, as humiliating as it was. I gave in and let Allie buckle me in. As Allie made her way to the driver’s seat, Libby looked at me and smiled, “It’s not bad sitting in a booster seat, Staci.”

“That’s easy for you to say.” Sighing, I said, “You’ve basically been in one your whole life.”

**************************


When we reached the mall, I quickly realized that walking was going to be a problem. Just walking the short distance from the car to the entrance had winded me. I knew what was coming, but I was still embarrassed when Allie came over with one of those tandem rental strollers. Could this day get any worse?

Even with the interview, I still got looks from people, as Allie pushed us through the mall as we walked into Sears to buy some clothes for Libby, since she’d had a growth spurt. While Libby was in the dressing room trying on some of the clothes, I stayed outside with Allie in the stroller. Looking at her, I said, “Why did you have to bring me?” frustrated, I said, “It’s bad enough that I’m shrinking; I don’t need to have it rubbed in my face that my 5-year-old sister is getting bigger.”

“That wasn’t my intent, honey.” Kneeling down, Allie said, “Your dad and I just thought you’d like to get out of the house for a while.”

Before I could say anything, an older woman came walking over to us. She seemed fixated on me for some reason; it was making me uneasy. Looking at me, she said ______.
111111111111111.title: Embarrassed at the Mall

1111111111111112.content:
"I've seen your face before, haven't I?" the woman said. Then it struck her. "You're one of those shrinking children. Staci, is it?"

"I suppose I am."

"Perhaps we can help each other, Staci," she said, as if I'd known her for years. "My name is Lauren Grey. I'm a dollmaker."

"Just because I'm shrinking, that doesn't change the fact that I outgrew playing with dolls years ago."

"You misunderstand me. I also make clothing for dolls, in all sizes. And I keep up with the latest styles. Would you like to try them?"

"Just a moment," Allie said. "What makes you think I'm going to allow her to climb into a stranger's car and go wherever?"

"I have some samples in the trunk of my car," Ms. Grey said. "I'll pick some out, and you may take them home and try them. If you like them, and if your friends would like some, here is my card." She gave a business card to Allie. "Do I still sound like a kidnapper?"

By this time, Libby was out of the dressing room. "What's going on, Mommy?"

"This lady is offering your sister some new clothes."

"Technically," she said, "I'm offering them to you. After all, it will be your credit card that pays for more."

Allie looked at me. "Would you like some clothes that are more your size?"

"Do you need to ask me that question?"

Allie turned back to Ms. Grey. "Alright."

"Splendid . Make your purchases, and then you can follow me out to my car."

We did.

At her car, Ms. Grey took some measurements of me, then rummaged through some boxes she had with her, coming up with eight outfits of increasingly smaller sizes. Not only that, but she also gave me some bras and panties, and some shoes. "I don't suppose you've got some tampons back there?" I asked.

"Now, that would be odd," she said. "I'm afraid you'll need to get creative in making pads for yourself." With that, Ms. Grey left.

Allie strapped us both back in our booster seats again, then drove to the entrance and returned the stroller.
1111111111111112.title: Aren't you one of those shrinking children?

11111111111111121.content:
I was anxious to show off my new clothes to the group, but first Allie decided to stop at McDonald’s for lunch. After sitting Libby and me at a table in the corner, Allie went up to place the order.

While she was gone, a woman came walking over to the table. She seemed quite interested in me; which, even after the interview, made me uncomfortable. “Aren’t you girls absolutely adorable.” Looking at us, she said, “I love it when sisters wear matching clothes.”

It hadn’t occurred to me until now that the outfits Libby and I were wearing were almost identical. I was about to correct the lady, saying I was actually 17, but Allie came walking over to the table. “Excuse me, can I help you?”

“I was just admiring your little girls.” Turning to Allie, with a smile, the woman said, “Children are so adorable at that age.”

“Actually the smallest one is my 17-year-old step-daughter.” Getting defensive, Allie said, “She’s one of the kids affected by that strange meteor.”

“Oh, I’m sorry.” Turning to me, the woman said, “I apologize if I embarrassed you.”

Sighing, I said, “It’s alright.”

The woman left a few minutes later; as Allie went to retrieve the order. I was upset to find that she’d ordered two Happy Meals, but I was hungry, so I decided not to do anything about it.

*************************

I must’ve fallen asleep during the car ride home; because I was startled awake by the sound of the door opening. As she went to unbuckle me, Allie said, “I see you’re taking after your sister.”

Glancing over at Libby, I saw that she was also asleep. “Can you blame me? I had to do a lot of walking today.”

“I’m afraid the days not over yet, honey.” Lifting me out of the car, Allie said, “Your father called on the way home; there’s some network executive at the apartment who wants to speak with the six of you.”
11111111111111121.title: A Brief Pit Stop

choices: Libby decides to tease me more.
1111111111111113.content:
I looked up to find an attractive, professionally dressed young woman with long brown hair and blue eyes looking down at me with a kind smile. Sighing, I softly replied, "Yes, I am."

I was not in any mood for another reporter, or for any questions from the curious. I had half a mind to politely ask the woman to leave me alone. Only I was caught off guard when she offered me a business card. "My name is Lauren Grey, owner and operator of Grey Line Dolls." Serious, she said. "I create dolls of all shapes and sizes, for children and adults of all walks of life." She then motioned to a display nearby. It was wearing the same outfit Libby had picked out. "Not only do I make the clothing for the dolls, I make them for the children who purchase them."

"Why are you telling me this?" Curious, I asked.

"I have clothing that fits the modern trends in your size, no matter how far you shrink." Simply, Lauren replied. "You don't have to settle for clothing made for a toddler or younger."

That caught my attention, as well as Allie's, who smiled. "Do you have any outfits with you for Staci to try on, Miss Grey?" Politely, she asked.

"Mrs Grey." Politely, Lauren said. "Also, please, call me Lauren. I have a shop right across the hall, if you wish to come take a look." She then motioned to a young girl no older than Libby, looking through a rack of clothes. "I was here with my daughter, Fawn, when I noticed you."

Fawn looked up, hearing her name, and smiled before shyly but politely waving. "Hi..."

"She's a bit shy, due to mine and my husband's work." Lightly, Lauren said. "But enough of that. Feel free to come to my store, if you are interested."

With that said, she walked back to her daughter to help her pick out an outfit. I turned to Allie, who was still smiling. "I guess it was a good thing that you went shopping with us after all," she said.

I blushed at that, but found it wise not to say anything, as Libby walked out, wearing a pair of denim overalls with a blue and white stripped short sleeve shirt with fluffed shoulders underneath. She giggled, twirling around once to show off her new outfit. "I love it!" Smiling, she said.

"I'm glad you do, honey." Kindly, Allie said. "As soon as we are done here, we will be going to the shop across the hall to buy Staci some clothing."

Curious, Libby looked out the door to the shop across the hall, and giggled again. "We're taking her to a doll store?" amused, she asked. "I got plenty of doll clothes..."

"Doll clothes were not made with people in mind, dear." Patiently, mom said. "The clothing your sister will be buying were made with people in mind."

"Huh?" Confused, Libby asked.

"Don't worry about it, and don't tease Staci too much, or you'll be grounded." Serious, Allie said. "Just like I grounded her last year for teasing you."

Libby pouted. "Okay..."
1111111111111113.title: An unexpected offer.

11111111111111131.content:
I don't know what I was expecting from the Grey Line Doll Shop, but it wasn't as much as was there. It was as big as my favorite stores from when I was full-sized. As Mrs. Grey promised, there were dolls of every size, from just as big as Libby to small enough to hold in your hand.

Allie got a big surprise from one section. "You make bras and panties for dolls?"

"We get a lot of little girls who like to dress their dolls just like people," Mrs. Grey explained. "As for anyone else,... Our official policy says we don't ask questions. It certainly works out for you six, doesn't it?"

"I don't suppose you make tampons, do you?"

"I can honestly say you're the first to ask for that. I'm afraid you'll have to be creative making pads."

"I like the prices," Allie said. "I can get clothes for the next month, for what I just spent on Libby's new clothes."

"I'm glad you like it," Mrs. Grey said. "And we've also got graduation gowns, for that special day."

Allie bought me a ton of new clothes. Then we went into the ladies' room, so I could change. Dressing like a teenager almost made up for the booster seat.

Allie picked up lunch at the drive-thru, and we were on our way home when Dad called. Allie put it on hands-free. "What's up?"

"How far away are you?"

"About 10 minutes. I've got lunch. Why?"

"There's a TV executive here who wants to make an offer to us and the kids."
11111111111111131.title: The Grey Line store.

111111111111111311.content:
When we got home, we found that my shrinking friends and most of their parents were in the apartment. They had all been talking about something, but that topic was set aside when the gang saw what I was wearing. Like me, they had never given Grey Line a second look, but finding out about their clothing line thrilled them. Even Quinn, more iconoclastic in her fashion choices, wanted to check the place out.

The parents who hadn't been there when we got home soon arrived with pizza, enough that Allie decided to put the food we'd gotten into the fridge for supper. With all of us present and accounted for, our mystery guest stood up.

"My name is Anthony Grey," he said, "and I'm a programming executive for Discovery. I think that audience interest in the cases of your children is strong enough for a two-hour time slot, so I'd like for us to discuss it."

"What, exactly, would this entail?" Dad asked.

"Our camera crews would follow the kids as they go about their daily lives. We'll culminate with graduation, letting viewers speculate on what lies ahead for you."

"How much following are we talking about?" I asked.

"Since you're minors, we won't film anything untoward. You can shoo us out of the room at any time, for any reason."

"I'm not completely convinced," Dad said.

"Perhaps this will help," Mr. Grey said. "We're prepared to offer $500,000 to each family."

That got all our attention. That amount would pay the medical bills from our quarantine. The gang and I put our heads together to discuss it.

When we reached an agreement, I whispered into Dad's ear, "We'll do it."
111111111111111311.title: A TV Show ?

1111111111111113111.content:
It took a while to iron everything out. By the time we were ready to begin, I was down to 3 feet tall. Libby loomed over me, just as much as I loomed over her a few months before.

I had an appointment with Dr. Kumar. Allie and Libby came with me, and the camera crew came along. "Why do you call your mother by her first name?" one of them asked.

"I'm not her mother," Allie said, "I'm her stepmother. I don't want to take her mother's place in her heart."

"Even though she doesn't want that place, either," I added.

******************************


"How have you been doing?" Dr. Kumar asked.

"I've been feeling alright," I replied. "I decided to go off my birth control pills. I know how crucial it is to get everything just right for them to work."

"I would like to get some blood work," she said, "just to see how your body is handling this."

I wasn't looking forward to that, but I knew Dr. Kumar was only thinking about my health.

I let the lab technician tie off my arm, and, since I was squeamish about blood, looked away as she brought the needle to my arm.

"Hm," said the lab tech.

"Holy shit," said Allie.

"Whoa," said Libby.

"What? What happened?"

"Sweetie, you need to look."

I looked.

The needle was bent.
1111111111111113111.title: Filming Begins

11111111111111131111.content:
The lab tech rushed out, returning with Dr. Kumar. She studied the needle, then took out another needle and tried again. It bent, too, I saw it. "Interesting." I got the feeling that she and the lab tech were a tough audience to impress.

"What could cause that?" Allie asked.

"I would hypothesize," Dr. Kumar replied, "that the radiation from the meteorite is causing your stepdaughter's molecular structure to become more dense." She got down to my level and looked me in the eye. "As you become smaller, your molecules are moving closer together, making you more resistant to injury."

"You're gonna be fun!" Libby said. Like a shot, she jumped out of her chair, ran up to me, picked me up, and spun me around, much faster than I ever spun her.

Part of the reason for that, you see, is because I get motion sickness. I'm okay in cars or buses, but put me on a boat, or a plane, or a roller coaster,... or pick me up and spin me around like a rag doll,...

"Eww!" Libby dropped me, and I yelped when I hit the ground.

"You know Staci gets motion sickness," Allie said. "You've teased her enough about it."

The lab tech cleaned up Libby's face, then Allie said, "Now apologize to your sister for dropping her."

"But I didn't hurt her!"

"Just because you didn't injure her, doesn't mean you didn't hurt her. She still feels pain."

"I'm sorry," she said to me. "Want me to kiss it and make it better?"

I rubbed my backside and looked at Allie.
11111111111111131111.title: I Can't Be Injured

111111111111111311111.content:
The next day, I got together with the group, and I told them about what had happened to me.

"I fell down a flight of stairs at the mall," Jesse said. "Mom was sure I'd be a pile of broken bones, but, except for some pain, I was fine."

"I was protecting Mr. Jingles from a stray dog," Quinn said. "I was bitten several times. I should have been mauled, but not even a scratch. My dads barely slept a wink that night."

The others all had similar experiences: something that should have maimed or killed them, but just caused some pain.

"Dr. Kumar thinks that our molecular density is behind it. We can't be injured, but we still feel pain."

"So what are we supposed to do with that knowledge?" Dave asked.

"Convince my dads to let me keep my cats?" Quinn suggested. "Or at least tell them they can take care of them."

"Enough of this," Jesse said. "Let's talk about graduation."

"Got my cap and gown all picked out," I said. "Based on how Teddie is doing, we can make a rough guesstimate what size we'll need." The bear was holding steady, and hadn't changed size since she was brought in.

That night, I tried climbing into bed, but wound up deciding to use the doggy steps Allie had bought online.
111111111111111311111.title: The Gang Gets Together

1111111111111113111111.content:
The last few days of classes had been a struggle, as I went under two feet tall. The mouse was getting harder to move, and it was getting harder for the teachers to notice when I raised my hand. Not to mention, my voice was soft and high-pitched, two qualities that made it difficult for the speakers at school to register when I was speaking. I know my friends had the same problems.

But all that was almost behind us. Today was the senior class's last day of school. All I had to do was tough it out one more day, and I would be done with school and 18 inches tall.

At long last, the final bell rang. I saw high fives given out like candy on Halloween, and well wishes all around.

After school, the six of us gathered in my living room. "How does it feel?" Allie asked.

"Not like I thought it would six weeks ago," Taylor said. "Back then, I was sure that I'd only see you guys again on TV, if that. Now, though, it feels like we're bound together."

"Shrinking has that effect, I guess," Dave said.

"What he's too afraid of looking like a big softie to admit he means," Quinn said, "is that we made it this far because we've got each other. If I had to do this alone, I would've gone completely nuts."

"Maybe you did," Tommy said, "and we just never noticed it because we're just as cray-cray as you."

Quinn gave him a hug. "I'll take it."

There was a knock on the door, and Allie answered it. "Is this a private party," Morgan Detweiler asked, "or can anyone join in?"

It wasn't just Morgan. All our full-sized friends came. And the party felt more like a send-off, at least for me. Morgan was going to FIT. Connor would play in the Big 10. These friends would live out the dreams we once had for ourselves.

They were the ones we wouldn't see again. It was the end.
1111111111111113111111.title: Last Day of Online Classes

11111111111111131111111.content:
"Again," I said.

Allie triple-checked the tape measure. "No change."

Two days ago, I had measured six inches tall. Yesterday, I was only a fraction of an inch smaller. Today, I was the same size. "Wanna call it?" I asked.

Allie nodded. "You've stopped shrinking!"

I cued up some party music on my phone.

Allie cheered. Dad wept tears of joy. Libby picked me up and carried me (she had learned to be more gentle when spinning me).

I was now one-twelfth my original size, or five and two-thirds inches tall. "Sixish," Allie called it, and I didn't mind that at all.

Later, we moved the party to the club room, and my best friends, who had also stopped shrinking, had an appropriately big celebration.

I had tried out Libby's dollhouse for a home, but it didn't work out. The mattress on the bed felt like a gym mat, and the comforter offered no comfort. So, with no other options, I stuck to sleeping on my big-girl bed.

Watching TV in my room felt like I was going to the movies. For something closer to the TV-watching experience, I used my phone.

Once, while sitting on the coffee table watching TV in the living room, I said to Dad, "My life has changed so much."

"Life always changes, sweetheart," he said.
11111111111111131111111.title: Finally!

111111111111111311111111.content:
On the bright side, I no longer had to sit in a booster seat.

It still felt undignified, though, being carried around in one of Allie's purses.

That's where I sat, though, on the stow-and-go between driver and shotgun, as we drove to the arena. Minicams mounted in the car recorded our chitchat as we tried to stay frosty. Finally, we arrived, and we took our places.

It had come as a surprise when the school asked me to address the graduating class. After all, they already had the valedictorian to deliver a speech. I figured that Mr. Grey must have put them up to it. Nevertheless, I wrote up something, and, when the time came, Allie carried me up and set me on the lectern with my phone.

"The world is full of possibilities," I said, "some we don't even know are there. With the lessons we've learned, however, and the friendships we've forged, those possibilities can become opportunities. With these tools at our disposal, we can face whatever waits behind the next corner."

Finally, it was time to receive our diplomas. Dad carried me up when my name was called, and he took the diploma, since it was bigger than I was.

We gathered at a table, away from the massive throng, and threw our caps in the air, just as our classmates did.

"Gavin?"

The voice was faintly familiar, but it was more Dad's reaction that clued me in to who it was. Soon, she arrived, and I recognized the face from the annual photographs I'd received.

"Staci? Is... is that you?"

My mother had arrived.
111111111111111311111111.title: Graduation

1111111111111113111111111.content:
My mother was nearly the mirror image of myself. Short and thin, by normal standards, with long blond hair, blue eyes and doll-like features. She slowly approached me, as if I were made of glass. I could not really blame her, the fact we were nearly indestructible never reached the ears of the press.

"I saw what had happened on the news, and came as soon as I could." Softly, she said.

"The news coverage was several weeks ago, Mira." In a guarded tone, Dad said. "Did you hit every red light on the way here?"

My mother, Mira, winced. "I suppose I deserved that." Softly, she said. "My career keeps me away most of the time."

Dad turned to me, noticing my confused expression. "Your mother is a supermodel." Calmly, he explained. "Discovered only a few weeks after you were born. Fame got to her, and I slowly became a Mr. Mom."

"Please understand, honey." Softly, Mira said. "Becoming a model was my childhood dream, I just could not let it go. Your father and I got a no fault divorce when you were about ten years old, and I left without you because I doubted you would like a life always on the move."

"Mira has been all over the world." Calmly Allie said. "She has appeared on calendars, billboards, commercials, and a few movies..."

"I'm here to offer whatever help I can give." Serious, Mira said. "i may not have been here when you needed someone the most, but I am still your mother."

I turned to Allie and Dad, who gave no indication of what I should or should not do. I turned back to Mira. "Why now?" Softly, I asked. I sharply looked up at her, tears in my eyes. "Why did it take this for you to come visit?!"

"I... was on a cruise." Blushing, Mira said. "No radio, no phones... just a way to get away from it all for a while. I heard of what had happened when I got back."

"That doesn't answer Staci's question." Firmly, Allie said.

Mira sighed. "No, I guess it doesn't..." She bit her lip. "The point is, I am here, and I can offer you all enough money to give Staci a good life." She then leaned in close to me. "As well as an offer you might find attractive."

"What are you talking about?" Protectively, Allie demanded.

Mira smiled. "Can you imagine the fame and fortune that Staci and her friends could claim as the world's smallest models?" Softly, she asked. She gave a dreamy sigh. "They could make all of the other doll lines pale by comparison."

Dad frowned. "That's the Mira I learned to know." Disappointed, he said.

"Absolutely not!" Taking me into her hands, Allie said. "Staci is a minor, and you no longer have any parental rights to her!"

Dad turned to me. "Staci, I leave this up to you." Firmly but kindly, he said. "If you want to hear your birth mother out, I'll let her stay." His frown deepened. "If you think you have heard enough, I will show her the door."

I turned between Mira, Dad, and Allie, not certain what to do...
1111111111111113111111111.title: My Mother

11111111111111131111111112.content:
I was grateful that the others were focused on their families, because I didn't want to have them hearing my family drama.

"You almost had me," I said, "right up until you mentioned modeling. The fact is, you've been a great advertisement against becoming a model."

"I don't know what you mean," Mira said.

"I mean Libby." I walked over and sat on Libby's hands. "She can be a pain, and she needs to learn that I'm not one of her dolls. But she's my sister, and I love her. When she needs her first bra, she's going to talk to me first. When she gets her first period, she'll come to me. And maybe down the road, she'll need my support. Maybe she'll get sick. Maybe some boy will leave her in the lurch with a baby on the way. Who knows, maybe she'll witness a meteor strike and find herself shrinking. Whatever happens, she'll need me, and I don't want anything to mean I'm not there for her."

Mira hung her head.

Dad nodded. "If that's all, Mira,... "

"Please," she said, "I meant what I said. Just let me do one thing for you, and then, if you never want to see me again, okay."

"One thing?"

"Just one. Anything your father can't do for you, I will."

I nodded to Allie, who took out the Grey Line catalogue. A lot of Grey Line merchandise could be considered high end, none more so than the Ultimate Dollhouse Collection. Doors closed with latches, not by friction. Drawers opened and closed. Closets had hangers for clothes. They could be plugged into the wall, allowing tiny LED bulbs to be turned on. They had working plumbing, with a reservoir of fresh water where the attic would be, and a waste water basin where the basement would be. They even had rear walls that slid out for putting in furniture.

"I like the Victorian one."
11111111111111131111111112.title: I have heard enough.

choices: The Whole Gang Has Reason to Celebrate
111111111111111311111111121.content:
Three days had passed since graduation, and I was thinking about how much my life had changed. While most of my classmates were figuring out what to do with their last summer before college, I had moved into a dollhouse my mother had bought me. And now, my big plans involved nothing more adventurous than going to the mall to pick out clothes.

"Good to see you again," Mrs. Grey said. "May I help you find anything?"

"We're looking at new outfits," Allie said. "Staci's mother bought her one of your Ultimate Dollhouses, and now she's got extra closet space."

"Perhaps a replica gown? It's not to period detail, but that might make it more appealing to wear."

As we shopped, Mrs. Grey kept up the small talk. "How was the big day? Any plans for the future?"

"I used to," I said. "I had been accepted by FIT."

"Ah," she said, getting a dreamy look in her eyes. "I remember FIT."

"You're an alumna?"

"You've got to start somewhere, and where better? But we were talking about you."

"I was going to go, but that was when I was five feet taller. Now, I can't even work a pair of scissors, let alone a sewing machine."

"Well, I can't let you throw away your dreams just because of your size. Suppose I made you an offer?"

"What kind of offer?"

"Why don't you take FIT classes online? You can design, and I'll turn your designs into reality. Plus, you'll be putting your lessons to work by working for me. What do you say?"

What could I say? My dream college, and an after-school job? One that would let me wear my own creations? "I say, I accept."

Needless to say, we celebrated when we got home.
111111111111111311111111121.title: An Unbeatable Offer

1111111111111113111111111211.content:
"I've got good news, guys," I said at my housewarming party. "I've been accepted for online classes at FIT."

"You're not the only one with news like that," Jesse said . "UConn still wants me. They said they'd honor my football scholarship, but they want me as a strategist instead of a quarterback. They say I'm sure to pick up visual details somebody else might miss."

"I've got a surprise for you guys," Tommy said, then stepped out the front door.

"ICE wants me," Taylor said. "They like my ideas for eliminating food waste. They say my size shouldn't be a problem."

"Harvard is still taking me," Dave said. "What do you think, too early to start calling myself the shortest President?"

"I think I've found my calling," Quinn said. "I want to help animals. Thanks to my size, they're not going to harm me."

Finally, Tommy returned, with a familiar-looking object slung over his shoulder. "That isn't... " I said.

I was never more happy to be wrong, as Tommy brought his new guitar around and began to play "Classical Gas" by Mason Williams. "My dad made it," he said. "And I've been accepted for online classes at Berklee."

"How about that?" I asked. "A few weeks ago, none of us thought we'd get into the colleges of our choice. Now, we're all going online."
1111111111111113111111111211.title: The Whole Gang Has Reason to Celebrate

11111111111111131111111112111.content:
I didn't expect much for my 18th birthday, since I already had a closet and a dresser full of clothes. But Dad surprised me. "I did some tinkering," he said. "Happy birthday."

I pulled away the wrapping to reveal a long, narrow cart. I was about to ask what it was for, when Dad showed me by putting my phone in it. "Now you can use your phone as a TV," he explained. "At night, when it needs a charge, you can just push it out the door."

"Thank you, Daddy," I said, then motioned for him to lean closer. When he did, I gave him a kiss.

A little adjustment of the volume was all that was necessary to use my phone as a big screen TV. Even better, Allie assured me that they couldn't hear it through the walls of my house, even though it was in the living room.

When the gang came over for my party, we only needed a few crumbs of cake.

We were watching the main TV when a news report came on. "A meteorite has crashed into Camp Rolling Hills in New Jersey. Reports indicate that, just as happened recently at Mystic Pines National Park, all those at the camp - campers, counselors, and the adult staff - have been shrunken by exposure to the meteorite."

It wasn't long before the phone rang. "That was the authorities," Dad said. "They'd like for you kids to talk to the folks at the camp, since you know what they're going through."
11111111111111131111111112111.title: My 18th Birthday

111111111111111311111111121111.content:
The upside to flying when you're under 6 inches tall: No need to pay for a seat.

The downside: It's hard to hold an air sickness bag open when it's bigger than you are. Also, nobody makes headphones in our size, so the in-flight movie is out.

But you can, and I did, take a nap on the tray table.

******************************


"Glad you could come," the doctor said, as we came out of our bags.

"How can we help?" I asked.

"The main issue is, the campers are scared out of their wits. So are the counselors and the staff, but they're putting on a brave face, except for one, who hasn't stopped crying since they realized they were shrinking."

"How small are they now?" asked Taylor.

"About one-twelfth what they were when they went to camp. They shrank much faster than you did."

"We were able to break camp and go home," Dave said. "A summer camp doesn't have that ability."

We went into the room where the shrunken campers were being monitored. The kids turned to see who had come in, and were surprised to see people closer to their size. "I thought they said we weren't contagious," said an older man, who we took to be the camp director.

"You aren't," I said. "We're the Mystic Pines Six."

Tommy calmed the kids down with his guitar. After two songs, he was taking requests.

"I suppose it was easier for us," Jesse said. "We shrank slower, so we could get used to it. But you'll adapt, just like we did."

"You stayed alive, under trying circumstances, until help could come," Dave said. "You did good."

I spotted one counselor, a young woman, crying in a corner, and recognized her as the one the doctor had talked about. I sat down next to her and rubbed her back. "Don't worry," I said, "things will be alright."

"No, they won't," she said. "They can't."

She produced a metal hoop. When she turned it to show me a gemstone, I realized it was a ring.

"I was supposed to get married, at the end of the season." She wiped her eyes. "What kind of a wife can I be now?"
111111111111111311111111121111.title: Visiting the Shrunken Camp People

1111111111111113111111111211111.content:
"The same kind of wife I can be as a mother to Staci." Smiling, Allie said. "If the man who proposed to you truly loves you, size will not matter."

"If he calls off the marriage because of your size, he is not the right man, and it is his loss." Serious, I added. "You helped these kids, and the other members of the staff, get through hell. That is the kind of woman you are."

The woman gave a tearful smile. "Thank you..."

She and I shared a quick hug before I motioned to Allie, who held up a number of small outfits from The Grey Line clothing store. "We sort of had to guess your sizes from the quick briefing we got from the authorities." Blushing, I said. "I hope they fit."

The woman smiled even more, grateful. "It'll be better than the itchy doll clothes they gave us, thank you again." Softly, she said. "I'm Nurse Sally Rook. I'll try these on real quick."

She ducked behind a small curtain that had been set up while I then turned my attention to the doctor in charge. Her name tag read Dr. Rita Norse. "Did anyone find anything new about these meteorites that are causing this?"

"Actually, we did." Serious, Dr. Norse replied. "They are pieces of a newly discovered comet NASA has called Nymph, which is slowly breaking up as it passes through our solar system."

I gulped. "So there may be more pieces coming our way."

Norse nodded. "NASA is working on a way to destroy the comet before that happens, but that is all we could get from them for now."

I nodded, then turned back to see Nurse Sally emerge, wearing a stylish pair of pants and blouse with a blazer, smiling. "This is so comfortable." Smiling, she said. "Where on Earth did you find these clothes?"

"The Grey Line Doll Shop." Smiling, I replied.

I then explained what the shop did, and what I will be doing to work there. When I was done, Nurse Sally smiled. "Well, I guess I could take online courses, earn my PhD, and become your primary doctor."

"It's an idea." Smiling back, I said.

Allie then turned to the other counselors. "These should fit you better than the doll clothes you had been provided." kindly, she said. "We brought some clothes for the kids as well."

The counselors thanked Allie, then took the clothing to the children, who gratefully moved to private areas to get changed. Only I spotted one girl who was hesitant to move. "Are you okay?" Kindly, I asked. "Are you hurt?"

The girl shyly shook her head, then reluctantly showed me a sleeping timber wolf cub she had hidden in her backpack. "It was scared and alone." Tearfully, she said. "I just couldn't leave the poor fellow out there."

I sighed then called over Quinn. "I think this is more your expertise." Softly, I said.

Quinn came over, saw the tiny wolf, and sighed as well...
1111111111111113111111111211111.title: Continue

11111111111111131111111112111113.content:
While Quinn stayed with the girl and her wolf, I turned my attention to the man I figured was the camp director.

He was sitting on a soda bottle cap that had been repurposed into a chair. Looking at him, I said, "How did this all start?"

"It was the second day of camp; everyone was down at the lake, getting ready for the swim test." Sighing, the man said, "Suddenly, out of nowhere, this rock slams into the lake and soaks us all with water."

"Let me guess what happened next: you dried yourselves off, and thought that was the end of it."

"That's right." Pausing, the man said, "It wasn't until a few hours later that we realized something was wrong, when we came across an adult goose the size of a duck."

"What happened next?"

"I called the authorities, and they quarantined the area." Gesturing to the kids, he said, "I have almost 2 dozen family members wanting to see their loved ones, but the authorities won't let them in."

"That can't be easy for the kids, or anyone, for that matter."

"It hasn't been easy." Looking at me, the man said, "This probably sounds terrible, but I'm glad there are others going through this with us."

"I wonder if the water somehow accelerated the effect? Oh, well, I suppose the next thing to do is figure where we go from here."

Before the man could say anything, the door to the cabin burst open to reveal...
11111111111111131111111112111113.title: Figuring Out What Happened

111111111111111311111111121111131.content:
"Good morning," Mr. Grey said. "Let me find a clear spot to sit down. I wouldn't want to sit on anyone."

"What brings you here, Mr. Grey?" Allie asked.

"I've got major news," he said, "and a major announcement. First, preview audiences are through the roof for the special. This is looking to sweep the ratings."

"I think we can guess what your announcement is, then," I said.

"You'd guess part of it, I'm sure," he replied, "but not the whole thing." He addressed the room. "How many of you would like to be on television?"

"I don't care to be gawked at, sir," replied the camp director.

"There'll be no gawking, I can assure you, sir," Mr. Grey answered. "Our idea is for those of you who have been affected by this Nymph comet to be set up in a village all your own."

"How is that going to work?" I asked.

"My network has secured a vacant apartment. In this apartment, we will place numerous dollhouses, from the Ultimate Dollhouse Collection. These will be your homes."

"The Ultimate Dollhouses are high-end," I said. "How are you going to get enough for everyone?"

"By asking nicely."

"You know," Allie said, "you and the owner of Grey Line have the same last name."

"Yes, we are married. But I still have to ask her nicely. I'm sure you already know that."

"What makes you think we want to live in some cheap dollhouse?" asked one of the counselors.

"Cheap?" Mr. Grey was clearly offended. "Ultimate Dollhouses are available only from Grey Line, which has furnished the very clothes on your back."

"He's not kidding about the houses," I said. "I've got one back home. They're quite realistic."

"Thank you. To continue: If you'd rather not live in a house, there are condominiums. And, while we couldn't put them in a commercially available dollhouse, we can install miniaturized appliances. And you can set up shops. It will be a village all your own."

"We're going to have to give this some thought," Allie said.

"Your daughter is an adult, she can decide for herself."

"And I'm going to think it over," I said.
111111111111111311111111121111131.title: Mr. Grey

1111111111111113111111111211111311.content:
The six of us gathered to call a meeting.

"I'm in," Taylor said. "I want to cook again."

"Fair enough," I said. "But we should also make some demands before we agree to do this. Like , we spend the holidays with our families, or things we want to do with them."

"Yeah," Jesse said, "and we can leave the show if we decide we don't want to do it anymore."

"And somebody in our families gets to do spot inspections," Dave added, "just to make sure nobody is held against their will."I

Once we had a good-sized list of terms, we gathered the adults from the camp and told them about it.

"We still need to talk to our families," said the camp director.

"Okay, that's the first thing: We don't agree to anything until you all get to talk to your loved ones." I relayed this to Mr. Grey.

Fifteen minutes later, the first meeting between patients and family members took place. I remained a respectful distance away, but I did observe the camp nurse's reunion with her fiance, and their body language indicated that his definition of "for better or for worse" included radical size difference.

By the end of the day, we and the network had agreed to terms.
1111111111111113111111111211111311.title: Meeting

11111111111111131111111112111113111.content:
"Thank you for signing on," Mr. Grey said. "I'm sure you won't regret it."

Mr. Grey was giving us a sneak preview of what he had planned for the new series, which he was calling Miniatures. I liked the title better than the tagline ("Real People. Real Stories. Real Tiny."), but I'm not in promotions. Giving us a preview was a simple matter, as the apartment they planned to use was in our building. (Lucky thing, as it would make spot inspections by Dad and the others easier.)

"Our layout is in the living room area. Mini-cameras will capture everything. The bedroom is where we'll monitor what's going on, particularly the things that make for good television. We'll also be using the kitchen and the bathroom. We have varying elevations, allowing for a more visually interesting layout, as well as - "

"Hey, guys" Quinn yelled, "a pool!"

"I take it," Mr. Grey said, "that's a bigger deal than I anticipated?"

"Suction units in full-sized pools could be hazardous to us," I said. "None of us wanted to test the theory."

"Ah. The landscape can be altered to simulate the outdoors. We have bare trees for the fall, a snowscape for winter. We'll even decorate the exteriors for Christmas, if you want."

"Where will the kids be staying?" Tommy asked.

"At home," Mr. Grey replied, "with their families."

"How come?" Dave asked. He had really come to like the kids.

"Have you ever tried to ask parents for permission to take their children away and hand them over to complete strangers to raise? Spoiler alert: It's a legal nightmare."

"So we don't get to see them at all?" Jesse asked.

"Some of them will have their own show. We're calling it Growing Up Miniature. Occasionally, we'll bring them by here, or you'll drop by there, get some cross-promotion going."

"That's too bad," Taylor said. "I would have liked to have more time with kids closer to our size."

"You didn't hear this from me," Mr. Grey said, "but, uh,... " - he pretended to look around - "one of the camp counselors is pregnant." He changed the subject. "I'll let you be the first to pick out your homes for the show. We'll give you clothes to wear, especially since it doesn't sound like you've got your own swimsuits. And, Staci? Why don't you have a look inside the market, see if anything catches your eye?"

He set me down in front of the market, which was laid out like a convenience store. There was food, beverages, candy,...

"TAMPONS!"
11111111111111131111111112111113111.title: The Village

111111111111111311111111121111131111.content:
It had been a week since the group had moved into the village – which was situated on two large tables in a corner apartment. The film crew had yet to provide us with miniature clocks, always saying they’d arrive on Tuesday, so it was a hassle to figure out what time it was.

I woke up to the simulated sound of wind and birds outside my window. Throwing off the covers, I climbed out of bed and walked to the window. My place was situated so I had a view of the park a short distance away. I could see a few people sitting on the benches, but couldn’t tell who they were.

After getting dressed in some jogging clothes, I grabbed a bottle of water and ran out the front door. Despite the best efforts of the film crew, I could still tell the environment was fake; the trees were the fake kind you’d find in a Christmas Village diorama. But I wasn’t complaining; it was still a decent place to live, even if there were cameras everywhere.

I jogged down the street to the market; which was really a distance of 8 feet but felt more like a mile. I walked into the store just as Grace, one of the camp counselors, came out. Looking down at her baby bump, I said, “Hey Grace, how are you feeling?”

“I’m feeling pretty good. The baby’s due date is in a couple of weeks.” Pausing, she said, “I had a chance to talk with my wife last night; I know she’s a bit confused about her role in raising our baby, but I reassured her that she’d be a part of its life.”

“There’s definitely no shortage of family turmoil here; between you and your wife, and Allison and her fiancé.”

“Speaking of which, how are things with Jesse and you?”

Jesse and I hit kind of a rough patch about 3 days into filming; he wanted to spend the night at my place, but I wasn’t sure I was ready for that yet. “We’re working things out.” Sighing, I said, “I hate to say it, but there’s not a lot of options when it comes to dating here.”

“I’m sure you two will work it out.” Smiling, Grace said, “You two have been friends for a long time.”

After saying goodbye to Grace, I continued my jog towards the park. I was just about to get there when I heard someone call my name. Turning around, I saw _______.
111111111111111311111111121111131111.title: The Show Begins

1111111111111113111111111211111311111.content:
"Need a lift?" he asked.

"No, thanks," I replied. "Almost there now."

"How about a rest?"

I caught on that he wanted to talk. "Alright," I said, climbing into the passenger seat. "Let me get this straight: a miniature gas-guzzler is easier to make than a clock?"

"It runs on AAA batteries, but I know what you mean." He took a breath. "I'm sorry."

"For?"

" I was ready to make our relationship physical again, and you weren't, and I pressured you. I should have understood that it's different for you, especially since you made friends with Grace so quickly. I'm sorry."

I kissed him on the cheek. "Accepted." I sat back in the seat. "Was this our first fight?"

"I don't know that I'd call it a fight. But, yeah, it's the first time it's been this tense between us."

"For Dad and Allie, this counts as a fight. I'd say it bodes well for us."

"I'll take that. Our first fight." He leaned towards me. "You know what comes next, right?"

I shot him a look.

He backed off. "Just kidding. See you later, hon."

As I got out, I kept thinking about the matter. Jesse was right. That is, he had sized up the situation correctly. Miniature condoms were even harder to get right than miniature clocks, and, even if they could make birth control pills in our size, they couldn't run blood tests to make sure the dosage was correct. That meant, if we wanted to make love, we had to risk getting pregnant.

But also, I had been thinking about us having sex ever since we'd moved into the village. Dad had made it clear that, even though I was under my own roof, I was still living in his home. Before we shrank, Jesse and I had talked about getting our own place one day, and everything that meant. Now, the opportunity was there, but I was scared.

But I wanted to make love, just as much as Jesse did. Hopefully, I could resolve this dilemma soon, before I drove myself crazy.

Ah, well, it made for good TV, right?
1111111111111113111111111211111311111.title: Jesse (In a tiny car)

11111111111111131111111112111113111111.content:
After spending some time in the park, I started back towards the house. I was about to go inside when I heard Allie’s voice behind me. “Hi sweetie, how are you?”

I hadn’t even realized there was a full-sized person in the room, probably because there were pads under the table to dampen the effects of people walking around. The first day after we’d moved in, it was like an earthquake every 5 minutes when someone walked by. Turning around, I smiled and said, “I’m doing pretty well, I guess.”

Bringing her hand down, Allie said, “Come on, let’s go talk in private.”

I hopped onto Allie’s hand and held on as she brought me over to the kitchen counter. Sitting on the edge, careful not to fall off, I said, “What do you want to talk about?”

“I just wanted to see how you were doing.” Leaning down to my height, Allie said, “I spoke with Jesse’s mom last night; she said you two had a fight.”

“He wants to resume our physical relationship, but I’m not ready yet.” Sighing, I said, “Believe me, I want nothing more than to be able to screw around with my boyfriend. But I don’t want to risk getting pregnant.”

“I can see how that can put a damper on any relationship.” Looking at me, Allie said, “But I’m sure you two will work it out soon enough.”

“I hope so.” Pausing, I looked at Allie and said, “How are things at home?”

“About as well as can be expected.” Smiling, Allie said, “Libby misses having you around.”

“I miss her too.” Smiling, I said, “You know she can visit, if she wants to.”

“I’ll keep that in mind, although I’ll have to remind her to be careful around the village.”

I chuckled at that, remembering an incident the second day, where a grape Libby was eating fell into the pond at the park and nearly flooded the area. “Please make sure she doesn’t have any grapes.”

“I’ll try my best.”
11111111111111131111111112111113111111.title: Allie Visits the Village

111111111111111311111111121111131111111.content:
