"It's getting scary," she said. "I'm the size of a little kid! How did you stand it?"

"I wasn't the only one. And you know that others have gone through this before you. You can do this."

"I'm glad one of us has confidence in m - Wait a minute. What's that?"

"What's what?" I replied, acting totally innocent.

"On your hand. What is - Oh. My. God. Is that an engagement ring?"

I held it up for a full view. "Jesse popped the question the night after you visited."

"I'm totally jelly. The guy I was dating cut me loose when I was still over five feet tall. Don't you let Jesse go for anything."

"I don't intend to." I did some quick calculating. "You should be done shrinking by our wedding day. Would you like to come? Maybe even be a bridesmaid?"

You'd think I had asked her if she'd like to meet the Pope. "You... you'd do that? For me?"

"I just offered to, didn't I? What do you say? You in?"

"I... yes. Yes, I'm in."

"Great. I'll call you soon with the deets. This really wouldn't have felt like my dream wedding without you, Morgan. I'm glad we made up."

She smiled. "So am I, Staci, so am I."
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: An Update from Morgan

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
The next day, I got a call from Mrs. Grey. "I'd like to have a word with you," she said, "about something other than the wedding."

"Okay," I replied. "What's on your mind?"

"I would like for you to do a commercial for Grey Line."

"Well, what would I have to do?"

"You would tell the audience about the craftsmanship and feel of clothing from Grey Line. At the end, we would reveal your size, and you would say that you were modeling the clothes the whole time. That's all."

"Well," I said, "I certainly won't say no right away. Send me the script, and I'll think it over."

"You won't regret it, Staci. Please call me when you've made your decision."

"I will. In any event, thank you for the offer. Goodbye."

I hung up and did some thinking, and not just about the commercial. My life was changing in so many ways. I was a college student, a reality TV star, and a designer for a major toy line. I was getting married. And, of course, I was ending the year considerably smaller than I was when it began. I wondered what steps I could take next, like any other adult.

Mrs. Grey sent me the script. Since it was a 30-second ad, it wasn't exactly War and Peace:

"Grey Line doll clothes are a bit more expensive than the competition, but what do you get for your money? Well, you get clothing in the latest styles, and fabrics that feel just like the real thing. There's nothing else quite like Grey Line. I should know. You see, I haven't just been talking about Grey Line clothes: I've been wearing them the whole time."

When I finished reading, I knew two things: I would do the commercial, and I would have to ask Allie to take me to see about my own bank account.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: A Commercial

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
When I called Allie, I cut straight to the point. "I'd like to set up a bank account in my name."

"Mr. Grey had already set up an account for each of you." Calmly, she said. "I set your username and password, and your friends' parents did the same for them."

"Why wasn't I told about this?" Curious, I demanded.

"You should have been sent a letter a while ago." Serious, Allie said. "Did you ever go to the post office in your village to get your mail?"

I blushed at that. "We have a post office?"

"You also have a bank." Calmly, Allie replied. "I suggest you visit them both."

"Mr Grey usually reads our fan mail to us." Embarrassed, I said.

"I'll talk to him about keeping you all better informed." Serious, Allie said. "Right now, I suggest you and your friends go to the bank and post office, to set up your own username and password, as well as get your mail."

After getting my username and password from Allie, I called all of my friends in the village and gave them the heads up. Within minutes, we all walked to the bank. It was near the center of town, with the post office right next door. As we entered, we were immediately aware of a TV wrist watch at each teller. TV wrist watches were a fad in the early eighties that died out with the coming of better iPhones. Each screen showed a real person, and we each took our turn talking to one of them.

"How may I help you today?" Politely, one of the tellers asked me.

I showed the teller my own miniature ID. "I'm Staci Parks." Politely, I said. " I would like to change my username and password."

The teller nodded. "Certainly. Please type in your new username and password, then hit enter."

I looked down to find a small keyboard, and entered my new username and password. Once it was done, I asked, "May I have my balance, please?"

I watched as the teller on the screen typed onto a keyboard, before a piece of paper printed out near the keyboard on my end. The number was staggering. I can pay off all of Allie's debts with this, and still have a fortune left!
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: At the Bank

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
Once I was done with my errands, I called up Allie. "I went to the bank, and the post office," I said.

"Anything interesting in the mail?" she asked.

"A few of the weirdest letters I've ever read. Somebody actually asked me about who bathes me. And word's definitely gotten out about the wedding, because my PO box was filled with offers. I'll share them with you next time. How much is this setting you back?"

"Sweetie, you let me worry about the cost of your wedding, okay?"

"But you don't have to worry. Literally, you don't." I read her my bank balance.

"Holy Jesus Christ. Where did that come from?"

"Ad revenues, Blu-Ray and DVD sales of the special, residuals. And an advance for the wedding special, with a share of the gross for the Blu-Ray and DVD sales. Send me your highest bills, and the bills for wedding expenses. I should still have a comfortable sum left over."

"Damn. You could be Scrooge McDuck if you wanted to."

I smiled. "'Get Small, Live Large.' That's my motto."

"Staci, I don't want to owe you."

"And you won't. You've given me so much when I was growing up. I'm paying you back."

"Well,... "

I played my ace in the hole. "You know that, if you say no, I'll just make the offer to Dad."

She smiled as if she had been treading water, and someone threw her a life preserver. "Thank you, Staci."
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: I Pay Off Allie's Debts

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
Friday saw Mrs. Grey bring me to the studio to shoot the commercial. "Have you ever been to a studio before, Staci?" she asked.

"No, ma'am," I replied. I was beginning to question why I was there. Anybody could tell you that I was no actress; how could I possibly justify being, not just the lead, but the only speaking part in a commercial?

"There's really nothing to be nervous about, Staci. Everyone here wants to help you do your best. I have confidence in you. I wouldn't have asked you to do this if I doubted you."

We went inside. "Excellent," said a man, "the talent's here. May I have a word with her?"

"Absolutely." Mrs. Grey set down her purse, and let me come out.

"How do you do, Ms. Parks? May I call you Staci? My name's Carruthers, I'll be directing you. Nervous?"

"A little." If I were full-sized, I likely would have turned and ran.

"Don't be. We're all friends here. No matter how many takes we have to do, we'll help you do this. And these crews get paid more the longer we're here, so don't worry about if we don't nail it right away. Do you need anything?"

"A glass of water, please."

"Not a problem. There's water waiting for you in your dressing room. Take a minute or two."

Mrs. Grey carried me into a room off to the side of the soundstage. On the makeup table was a place set up just for me, with makeup, a chair, and bottled water chilling in a shot glass full of shaved ice. "I'll be back later, dear," she said, "with your wardrobe." As she left, I opened up a bottle of water and drank.

I was feeling better. I wasn't being asked to play a character, after all, but to be myself. I knew what Grey Line clothes looked and felt like, all I had to do was say so with a camera rolling. It was just like the show.

Mrs. Grey knocked before entering. "I've brought your clothes," she said. "I'll give you ten minutes to get ready."

The clothes were a lot like what I was already wearing, except I had a green T-shirt on, and they wanted me to wear pink. I put on the shirt, then did my makeup, then put on the rest.

When I was finished, Mrs. Grey took me to the set, which consisted of a table draped with green cloth, with a green screen behind it.This is why I couldn't just wear my clothes, I thought to myself. They would be inserting me over other images, and my green shirt would be a distraction. There was also a ruler propped up on the table, for the end of the spot, when I reminded people that I was wearing Grey Line clothes.

I got through the commercial, and I only took two or three takes to do it.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: The Commercial

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
The next day, we all sat down together with Rev. Roney, of the United Church of Christ, to discuss the ceremony. "This is to be an actual wedding, is it not?" he asked. "Not one of those reality television stunts?"

"It's real, Reverend," I assured him. "Jesse and I love each other, and we want to proclaim that love to everyone."

He relaxed. "In that case, we would be honored to be the venue you select for your ceremony. If I may ask, how should we accommodate your... stature?"

"The current plan," Allie said, "is to carry them on platforms. If you have a better idea, we'd be delighted to hear it."

"Not at this time, no. What music have you selected?"

"We want traditional music throughout," I replied. "The most recent compositions are 'The Wedding Song' and an instrumental version of 'Sunrise, Sunset' for the seating of Jesse's mother and Allie."

"You don't call her Mother?"

"I'm her stepmother," Allie explained. "Her calling me by my first name was my decision."

"I'm sorry. I didn't mean to offend."

"None taken, Reverend. So, are we in agreement?"

"I'll want to meet with you a few more times," he said, "to iron out the particulars. But I don't see a significant problem. If you'll have us, we'll have you."

"Thank you, Reverend," I said. "You don't know how happy you've made us."

Bit by bit, the wedding was coming together.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: Meeting with the Minister

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
The average customer at the Grey Line Doll Shop might have wondered why two women and someone the size of a preschooler were escorted by sales clerks to a back room. Those who actually knew us, on the other hand, would have recognized them as Allie Parks, Mrs. Larson, and Morgan Detweiler. The three of them placed their open purses on the table, and Taylor, Quinn, Holly, and I stepped out.

Presently, Mrs. Grey joined us. "It looks like everyone's here," she said. "Shall we begin?"

"Let me warn you, Staci," Quinn said, "I'm allergic to taffeta. I break out in flying fists."

"I will want you in a dress," I replied, "but I don't want you in anything hideous." To Mrs. Grey, I asked, "Do you have any suggestions?"

"As a matter of fact," she replied, "I do." She placed on the table a doll dressed in a camisole, an ankle-length skirt, and a shawl, all in lilac.

My bridesmaids examined the outfit. They all seemed pleased with the recommendation.

"And, for the maid of honor," Mrs. Grey said, before placing another doll onto the table. This doll was dressed in the same clothes as the previous one, but these clothes were in lavender. This, too, met with her approval.

"Now," Mrs. Grey said, "your gown isn't ready quite yet, Staci. But I have an A-line gown, to give us an idea of how you'll look on your special day."

I stepped behind a curtain to try it on.

When I came out, I was met with a round of applause.

I changed back into my street clothes, we got back into our purses, and we left Grey Line. On the way out, the taller ones among us met with several men going in. Presumably, these represented Jesse; his best man, Dave; and his groomsmen.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: Dressing the Wedding Party

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
Later in the week, Dad, Allie, Jesse, and I went to the printer's to order the invitations. I had thought it would be a straightforward process, but it turned out there was a lot I didn't know.

"Delighted to meet you," the printer said to me. "May I call you Staci?"

"That's fine."

We got through the questions I figured would be asked, but I was surprised when he asked if Allie was my birth mother. "Why do you need to know that?" I asked.

"Well, Staci," he explained, "there is a tradition behind every word in a wedding invitation. Look."

He turned the monitor, and I saw the simulated invitation:

Mr. and Mrs. Gavin Parks

request the honor of your presence

at the wedding of Mr. Parks' daughter

Staci Elizabeth

to

Jesse Larson


"Now, you're getting married in a house of worship, so we say 'honor of your presence.' If you were getting married in a secular location, we would say 'pleasure of your company.'"

He pointed to the next line. "Allie fills the role of mother of the bride, but she is not your mother. Therefore, we do not say you are her daughter. See?"

I nodded. "It makes sense, when you put it like that."

"That's what I'm here for."

"So," Jesse asked, "where on the invite do we put the registry?"

"You don't," the printer replied. "That would be tacky. What we do is, we insert a separate card, directing your guests to your wedding website. There, you provide a link to your registry. This preserves the happy illusion that you think having people show up at your wedding is present enough, and the gifts are a pleasant surprise."

"Makes sense," I said.

Once we got through the particulars of the design, the printer said, "If you don't mind my asking, there is a practical matter to consider. Traditionally, the bride addresses each envelope by hand. Now, that's worked well for hundreds of years, but... "

"But the pen is almost as big as I am," I finished.

"I'll take care of addressing the envelopes," Allie said.

That took care of that matter, but it did get me thinking: How were we going to handle the other times when a signature would be needed? Like the marriage license? Like requesting the marriage license?
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: Invitations

choices: Taking a Break from Planning the Wedding
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
A couple days later, Dad brought me back to the apartment. "I've got something I want to show you," he said, "and I couldn't wait until the weekend."

It wasn't often that I saw Dad excited, and it was making me excited, too.

When we got to the apartment, Dad set me down in front of what was obviously what he wanted to show me. What I could see was a plastic device with a touch screen at a 45-degree angle. "What does it do?" I asked.

"Write something on the screen with your finger," he replied, "and press Enter."

There was a line on the screen, along with two buttons: Clear and Enter. Looking at the screen, I wrote the one thing that had been on my mind lately: Mrs. Staci Larson

When I hit Enter, the device began to hum. When it stopped, Dad lifted it, revealing a piece of paper underneath.

On that paper were the words Mrs. Staci Larson, in my handwriting. Big enough for anyone to see.

I brought my hands to my face as the meaning of this hit me: I would be able to sign any document, just like anyone else.

"What do you think?" Dad asked.

"Pick me up, Daddy, and hold me tight." I wanted to hug him so much.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: Finding the Answers

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
Jesse and I decided to take a break from planning our wedding to enjoy our company for a while, with a picnic in the park. There was everything to make anyone happy, as an adult or a kid at heart, including a small batting area, swings, slides and picnic areas. I smiled, seeing the children from the summer camp playing there, just being kids. It was good to know they had a place to go, to forget they were very tiny people in a giant world. We set up a spot near the gazebo to have our picnic, where we enjoyed a peaceful lunch together.

"It's almost as if nothing has really changed." Smiling, I said.

"Except we are all still together." Kissing me, Jesse said.

He and I began to make out until we heard giggles, coos, and whistles from some of the kids, who ran off laughing after we turned their way. "What are you going to do?" Ruefully, I asked.

"Let them giggle, coo and whistle." Smiling, Jesse said. "Here, they can just be kids. Let them have their fun." He then kissed me again.

Before long, we were making out again, despite the unintended audience, who eventually left us to their own activities. "What shall we do now?" After the picnic, I asked.

"How about we check out that new movie playing?" Smiling, Jesse asked.

"Which one?"

"If I Could Turn Back Time." Calmly, Jesse replied. "It's about a boy who returns home after vanishing for six years, not having aged a day." He chuckled. "Form what Dave told me, crazy things start happening shortly after."

"Sounds interesting." Smiling, I said.

We went to see the movie and Dave was right. It was a wild and crazy movie, but worth the watch, as we both left the theater in good spirits. "That poor boy." Giggling, I said. "At least he came out on top in the end."

"Just as we did." Kissing me, Jesse said. "All due to a rock from the sky."

Upon returning home in a good mood, my iPhone, which doubled as a big screen television, rang, and I answered. It was Mr. Grey. "Hello...?"

"I hate to ruin your day, Staci but the last piece of the Nymph comet has crashed to Earth." Serious, Mr. Grey said.

I sighed. "Where?"

Mr. Grey sighed, not a good sign. "Staci, it crashed..."
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: Worry free, worryful.

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
"... into an amusement park."

My heart sank. I envisioned hundreds of people finding themselves shrinking: families, couples, maybe even a scout troop. "How... how many... ?"

"That's the good news, Staci: it's the off-season. And there are no signs that anyone broke in for a little free fun. Hazmat teams will collect the fragments and sanitize the area. Then, it's up to the park owners to make repairs."

I understood. The sigh I had heard was one of relief. "You're sure nobody was affected?"

"I'm as confident as I can be. Only birds seem to be affected. And, while I'm sure Quinn would like the new patients, we all know that collecting them would be next to impossible. Relax. You will have enough stress in the days to come, what with your wedding. Goodbye."

Jesse hugged me. "Relax, honey. Allie's sending out the invitations. Most of the preparations have been made; we're just waiting for RSVPs, so we can reserve hotel rooms. And now we know about the last piece of Nymph. It's going to be okay."

I wanted to believe him. But I kept thinking about Mira. Whoever made the pills that shrank her got the stuff somewhere.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: into an amusement park.

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
Taylor was the one throwing my bridal shower, but Allie had graciously given the apartment as a location. She and Mrs. Larson sat down at the table, while Morgan (down to a foot tall) and those of us from the village sat down on the table, around an analog clock.

"Now, Staci," Taylor said, "you may be wondering why we're sitting around this clock? Well, it's because that's the theme for your bridal shower: Around the Clock."

After a couple of games, Taylor had me open presents. "Because the theme is Around the Clock, your gifts will represent the hours of the day. And your day begins at 6:00 AM." She handed me her gift.

When I opened it, I couldn't believe my eyes. "An alarm clock?!"

"Yeppers. They've finally got the bugs out of miniaturizing clocks. And you, my best friend, get the very first one."

7:00 AM was a set of bowls. 8:00 AM was a toaster.

9:00 AM was a tea service. 10:00 AM was a crock pot. 11:00 AM was a coffeemaker.

Noon was salad plates. 1:00 PM was a panini press.

2:00 PM was bakeware. 3:00 PM was a cake stand. 4:00 PM was cake plates.

5:00 PM was a set of pots and pans. 6:00 PM was flatware. 7:00 PM was dinner plates.

8:00 PM was new towels. 9:00 PM was new bed linens.

10:00 PM was fuzzy slippers. And 11:00 PM was a nightie that I never thought I'd show Allie.

Before the party was over, Taylor had one more trick up her sleeve. Someone had written down the things I'd said during the party, and these were repackaged as things I might say on my wedding night. And I said a lot of things, like "How did you know I wanted this?", and "And people actually do this deliberately?" We all laughed.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: The Bridal Shower

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
About two days later, I stepped out of my house to run a few morning errands, when I heard a giggle from above, and looked up to find Mrs. Grey grinning down at me. "Fee Fie Foe Fum..." Teasing, she said. "I smell a girl who's had too much rum."

I giggled. "That's so lame..." Bemused, I said.

Mrs Grey shrugged. "I was only given two hours to come up with something."

With that, she scooped me up in her two hands, covering me completely, before walking off with me somewhere. I trusted her, so I really wasn't spooked, but then she gently placed me down a moment later, and i found a black cloth bag being thrown over my head. Now I was worried, as someone pulled me through a doorway and slammed it shut. Before I could react, the cloth was pulled off of me, and I found myself in an open roof building, with what looked like a runway in the middle of the main room.

Then I heard a chorus of voices yell, "Surprise!"

I looked around to find all of the girls I had met in my adventures, surrounding me, including the family doctor, Lisa Kumar; Mrs. Grey; and her daughter, Fawn. "Welcome to your bachelorette party, Staci." Smiling, Quinn said. "The theme, as you may have guessed, is a runway show."

"I-I hope you don't mind me being a part of it." Timidly, a voice said.

I turned to find Morgan, who was now no taller than I was. I sighed seeing her, and gave a warm hug. "Of course, I don't." Smiling, I said. "Thank you for coming."

With that, the party began with games, including crazy outfits which we all had to take turns showing off. Next was one of the men from the summer camp doing a little tease dance on the runway, which brought a lot of whistles and cheers from us. Fortunately, the little girls of the group were kept occupied in other rooms, with their turn to walk down the runway when it happened. We all laughed when Hannah asked us, "Why are you all blushing?"

Next came the presents, which were presented to us down the runway. One made me blush, as it was a pair of fuzzy handcuffs with two sets of keys. "Really, Taylor?" Half giggling, I asked.

Taylor shrugged. "You never know..."

Other presents included sexy lingerie, a cocktail recipe book, a wishing bracelet, I Said Yasss Engagement Ring T-Shirt, Here Comes The Bride embroidered jean jacket, and so much more. By the time the party ended, I was wondering how Jesse's Bachelor party was going.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: The Bachelorette Party

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
I was still in a good mood when I got home. Then, the phone rang.

It was Mr. Grey. "Hello, Staci. Is Jesse in?"

"He's having his bachelor party. What's up?"

"A rather serious matter, I'm afraid. Several fragments of Nymph have gone missing from NASA's storage."

I shook my head. "How do you steal radioactive material that will shrink you if you're exposed to it?"

"I know how to do it legally. Unfortunately, that makes me a suspect. I thought you should hear about it from me."

"What do you need me to do?"

He smiled. "I need you to put it out of your mind, as much as possible. I'll worry about Nymph. You worry about what happens in two weeks. Goodnight, Staci."

Right after I hung up, Jesse came through the door. Staggered through, to be exact.

"Fee, fi, fo, fum," I said, "I smell someone who's had too much rum."

"Yer byoo-ful," he said.

"And you're hammered. Remind me to tell Tommy that, if he wants you so drunk that you can't climb the stairs, you should bunk with him." I let him sleep it off on the sofa, and put a basin nearby, should the need, among other things, arise. Then I went upstairs for bed.

Now, I had a lot on my mind that night. The missing Nymph fragments, an inebriated fiance, lingering good feelings from my bachelorette party. Not to mention that big event that was now just under two weeks away.

So maybe you can understand why I ignored the fact that my pad, which should have told me that Aunt Flo had come to town, was instead telling me that she was late.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: After the party

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
It's not every day that you wake up having to throw up. So, when that's how my day began, I started thinking about why.

Okay, first I cursed my existence, but then I thought about why.

My first guess was nerves. I was less than 48 hours away from getting married. I was just nervous.

And then this still, small voice asked, But is it just nerves?

What else could it be?

What else, indeed?

That's when it hit me: My period was late. Two weeks late, specifically. My nerves played a part, but only to distract me from what was happening.

Jesse knocked on the bathroom door. "You okay in there?"

"I think I'm pregnant."

Jesse opened the door. "Are you sure?"

"Well," I replied, "I haven't seen any pregnancy tests in the store, and, even if I could give blood for a blood test, there isn't enough in me to test. But my period's hella late, and my stomach thinks I'm flying to China."

Jesse knelt beside me. "We'll check later, okay? I'll make some tea."

******************************


Later that morning, Dad came to take us to get the marriage license. Thanks to his invention, Jesse and I could sign for the license as easily as we paid for it.

Once we had the license, Dad took us back to the village, where we said goodbye until tomorrow. Then, we went to the store. Luckily, some pregnancy tests had just come in. We were, apparently, the first to buy them.

So, we went back home, and I took the test.

And so began the longest ten minutes of my life.

Finally, the test was ready. Bracing myself for whatever it said, I went into the bathroom and read the test:

Pregnant


When I came back out, I didn't need to say a word. The smile on my face told Jesse everything.

He didn't need to say anything to me, either. The way he lifted me to the sky said it all.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: The Day Before the Wedding

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
"Nervous?" Taylor asked, as she helped me with my makeup.

"A little," I replied. Also a little pregnant, I thought, but didn't say. I'd reveal that when the time was right.

"You've got nothing to worry about. Everybody wants to see you get married. Jesse's just at the other end of the building. And you didn't hear it from me, but your design for your gown leaked, and big people have started asking for it." She fastened my gown.

Allie knocked. "All ready to go?"

"All set," Taylor replied. "Give us a lift?"

Allie picked us up and carried us to the back of the church, then went to stand next to Mrs. Larson. They nodded, and the violinist struck up "Sunrise, Sunset", letting the guests know that the wedding was about to begin.

The music changed, which cued the attendants carrying the bridesmaids and groomsmen to bring them up to the altar.

I turned to Dad. "I wish I was full-sized, for just a little while," I said, "so I could lean on you for strength."

Dad gave me a slight smile. "I was wishing the same thing. Only I wanted to lean on you."

The ensemble played Clarke's "Trumpet Voluntary", which was my processional music. Dad carried me to the front of the church, where we paused so I could give a tiny rose from my bouquet to Allie, and another to Mrs. Larson. Then he brought me to the altar where Jesse stood waiting.

Friends gave readings. Rev. Roney's sermon was followed by Tommy performing "The Wedding Song (There Is Love)" on guitar. We said our vows. We gave each other rings.

"By the power vested in me," Rev. Roney said, "I now pronounce you husband and wife. You may kiss."

He didn't need to say it twice.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: The Wedding

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
The reception was at a banquet hall in the same hotel where we put up our out-of-town guests. A conveyor belt had been set up temporarily, to bring the wedding party directly to the head table. We were heralded by "Good To Be Alive (Hallelujah)" , and none of us could resist boogieing our way down the belt. Good thing I had removed the train, and traded my pumps for flats.

Before we ate, it was time for toasts. (Don't worry, I made sure I had ginger ale instead of champagne.) Allie's was the one that stuck with me: "If we were to measure based on the capacity for love, then I am in the presence of giants."

I stepped up to the microphone. "I want to thank you all for being here," I said, "and being part of our day. Today is the happiest day of my life, and I know it's so cliche to say that. But I want you to know that it was a close decision." I took a breath. "You see, yesterday, I found out that I'm going to have a baby."

That got more applause than I expected.

We all sat down to eat, which meant it was time for the grand tradition of the guests tapping their glasses with their flatware to demand we kiss. After a while, I had to ask Jesse, "What do they think, I'm going to get more pregnant?"

Then came the cake cutting, and I was, and am, so glad I told Jesse not to smear cake on my face. If we have a girl, I'd like for her to at least consider wearing this gown.

For the first dance, we chose "(I've Had) The Time Of My Life", and you know we recreated the scene. It seemed to work, as people clapped and cheered at the right places.

A barstool was brought in, to serve as a dance floor for the father/daughter dance and the mother/son dance. Then the dance floor was open to everyone, and the sight of my father tearing up the dance floor will stay with me forever.

On a completely cheerful note, Quinn found a foolproof method for keeping the guitar out of Tommy's hands without him complaining: she put herself there first.

Finally, with the last dance, we bade farewell to our guests.

******************************


All in all, it wasn't the wedding of my dreams.

I never dreamed I'd be less than six inches tall. I didn't dream I'd be carried from place to place. And I certainly never dreamed I'd be 18, a freshman, and pregnant.

But the thing about my dream wedding was, when it was over, I wasn't really married.

I was now.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: The Reception

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
The next morning, Mrs. Grey came to take us on our honeymoon trip. "Good morning, Mr. and Mrs. Larson," she said. "And how are you today?"

"I think 'as well as can be expected' is how we'll put it," Jesse replied.

That's because his bride was, at that moment, not so much blushing as hurling.

"I love you, baby," I said, once I was able to open my mouth without dinner and wedding cake coming back out. "But why are you doing this to me?"

"When you say 'baby,'" Jesse asked, "do you mean me, or the actual baby?"

"Both of you."

Finally, my stomach settled down, and, after a cup of tea and a cracker, I was ready to go.

"I brought you a surprise," Mrs. Grey said, as we climbed into her purse.

After a few moments, I found it. "Ginger snaps?"

"They were a lifesaver when I was pregnant with Fawn. And sailors have been using ginger to tame seasickness for millennia, so it just might make the flight a little more bearable for you, too."

I shrugged. "I've got nothing to lose, except a few of these."

******************************


Well, they worked, at least against motion sickness. I'd have to wait until tomorrow to see how they did against morning sickness. But ginger snaps were definitely going on my shopping list for my next flight. I was actually able to eat fragments of Mrs. Grey's in-flight meal peacefully, washing it down with a bottle of milk (miniaturized, so it technically didn't exceed the legal limit on liquids). The movie was still no good for us, but we had a tablet and Wi-Fi.

******************************


After Mrs. Grey collected her luggage and our Airstream, we checked into the hotel. For now, we would recover from jet lag. Tomorrow, we would go to Madurodam.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: Off to the Honeymoon

choices: After the tour, our hotel room.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
Jesse and I were taken to Madurodam inside Mrs Grey's purse, where she talked to the tour guide before letting us out on the main street, behind the barriers that kept regular tourists off the tiny streets and well out of reach of anyone's curious hands. We were met by a small group of people our size, which greatly surprised us.

"Goedemorgen, mevrouw en mijnheer." Politely, the first man said. "Good morning, sir and ma'am. Welcome to Madurodam."

"Thank you." Kindly, I replied. "I honestly thought I would never meet anyone our size."

"We tend to keep a low profile and stay indoors during tourist hours." Calmly, the man said. "I am George Witt, Mayor of Madurodam. The people behind me are my council. We work together to make laws that are fair and workable for everyone."

"I saw on the brochure that you even have an airport." Smiling, Jesse said.

"That is just for the tourists." Lightly, a young woman replied. "I am Lydia Moore, chief of police in this thriving community."

"I'm Staci Parks, and this is Jesse Larson." Politely, I said. "We're here on our honeymoon."

"You could not have picked a better place." Smiling, George said. "I can recommend a few fine restaurants and a couple great shows."

"We'd appreciate that." Smiling, I said.

"Um,... if you don't mind me asking,... what happened?" Wincing, Jesse asked.

"You of course know of the Nymph comet." Serious, Lydia said. "Well, it has a few sisters."

Both Jesse and I were floored by that revelation. "Why were we not told of this?" shocked, I asked. "When did you get affected?"

"Would you want the world to know there were several comets that could potentially shrink entire cities?" Serious, George countered. "Madurodam was a real city, back in the early 1700s."

"One of the many sisters of Nymph crashed on this very site, shrinking the entire city and everyone in it." Calmly, Lydia added. "The only one not to shrink rebuilt the city here in De Haag, as a tribute to those who were killed in the tragedy."

"We are the descendants of the survivors." Smiling, a small girl said, reading off of a card. She handed Jesse and me each a single rose. "I am Gretel Witt. It's my job to welcome guests to our city."

George smiled. "She wanted to meet the people as small as we were." Bemused, he said.

Jesse and I both smiled at the girl, who was no older than four. She innocently smiled back before taking both Jesse's and my hand. "Come on, I'll show you around."

Both George and Lydia chuckled as the little girl led us by the hand into the streets of Madurodam.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: Madurodam

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
The Netherlands will be the first to tell you that, if you miss one or two of their historic buildings on your tour, you can make up for it by visiting Madurodam. For people our size, Madurodam is a way to tour the Netherlands the way big people do. Jesse and I got to see the sights and enjoy the local cuisine, just like any other couple on their honeymoon would do. The people of Madurodam could not have made us feel more welcome. They even forgave my attempts at speaking their language. I resolved that, when we got home, I would put real effort into learning more languages. After all, what kind of fashion designer would I be otherwise?

The curiosity wasn't just a one-way street. They wanted to hear about our village back home. And Gretel wanted to know everything about the baby I would be having. With the aid of their own tablet, I was able to answer almost every question she had (I left it to her folks to tell her how the baby got inside me).

It was the most wonderful two weeks I'd ever spent. And, thanks to the ginger snaps, even my morning sickness didn't spoil it too much. Before Mrs. Grey came to pick us up, the night before our return flight, we exchanged addresses with our new friends, promising we would keep in touch.

"You seem like you enjoyed yourselves," Mrs. Grey said, back at the hotel room.

"Immensely," Jesse said.

"Thank you for suggesting that we come here," I added. "And how did your time here go?"

"Splendidly. Grey Line is very close to going international, and I picked up some designs for European clothing. On your next visit, you may even see our clothes on the streets of Madurodam."
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: A tour of the city.

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
Thankfully, folks in the village gave us a day to recover from jet lag. So, the next day, we were ready to talk to people again.

"How's married life?" Holly asked.

"Good so far," I replied.

"And the baby?" Taylor asked.

"Should be okay. Mrs. Grey told me about ginger snaps, and they're working wonders."

"How was the Netherlands?"

"Surprising. I'll tell you all about it later." First, though, I wanted to check in with Nurse Sally. I wanted to make sure I was healthy, so I could make sure the baby was healthy.

When I got to her office, however, I couldn't help but overhear her talking to someone else. "I can't believe you did this," she said. "What were you thinking?"

"You didn't want to marry me," a man replied, "that's what I was thinking."

"But it cost you so much! And you had no idea it would work."

"I had to take a chance. I had to give us a chance."

I knocked on the door frame. "Is this a bad time?"

"Huh? Oh, hello, Staci. Welcome back. My fiance and I were having a discussion."

"Fiance? But wasn't he - "

"Some people offered to shrink me," he explained, "so I could be with Sally. Cost me half my savings, but well worth it."

"I don't even know how you did this," Sally said.

"I do," I replied. "Nymph had at least one older sister. And fragments have gone missing from NASA."

"What? Why weren't we told about this?"

"To avoid a panic. Imagine the reaction if people knew there was enough material to make missiles capable of shrinking some major cities."

Sally sighed. "I guess we should count our blessings that whoever stole that stuff has decided they can make more money shrinking people individually."

******************************


Sally said I was just fine, which meant that chances were the baby was fine, too. She made some dietary recommendations, and said she'd see me in a month.

I went to the store to do our shopping. My thoughts were full of so many things, maybe it shouldn't be surprising that I bumped into someone. "Sorry," I said, "my mind's a million miles away."

"Quite alright," the woman replied, "it happens to us... Oh, dear."

I couldn't believe my eyes. "Mira?"
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: Back at Home

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
"What happened to you?" I asked. "The last I saw you, you were over two feet tall."

"I got a message from someone," Mira told me, "saying they had a way to shrink me small enough for the village. Normal life was off limits to me. I had to do something."

"An anonymous stranger contacts you," I said, "right after an anonymous party shrinks you to half your size, and it doesn't set off a single warning bell for you?"

"I was past caring," she replied. "I... used the opportunity for a cleanse - "

"You don't need to worry about what I think of you, mother. Just say you went off drugs cold turkey."

She sighed. "Fine. I was seeing things clearly for the first time in years, and I realized what a mess I'd made of things. My lifestyle had cost me the love of my only daughter, and all I had to show for it was a child's wardrobe. They could have offered me a gun and a bullet, and I probably would have taken them up on it." She took a breath. "I'm not looking to rebuild our relationship. Treat me like you would any of the other people here."

I nodded. "Alright. Welcome to the village. Treat people right, and they'll treat you the same way. And you should hear it from me before anyone else: I'm pregnant."

"Congratulations, Staci. I hope Allie was a better influence than I was."
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: Mira

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
Once I'd gotten everything put away, the phone rang. I answered it. "Hello?"

"Hello, Staci," Allie said. "How are you? What are you up to?"

"Getting ready for baby," I replied. "I saw the nurse, and I got some prenatal vitamins. And I bumped into Mira."

"Mira? What was she doing there?"

"She's moved in. Someone shrank her to our size. She asked me not to treat her like she's my mother, and I don't plan to."

"Still," Allie said, "you'll be seeing more of her than you've seen in a long time. How are you holding up?"

"I think it's really hit me that I'm going to be a mother. I'm glad I had you to teach me how."

"It's going to surprise you."

"What is?"

"Once you actually hold that little one in your arms, you'll find levels of love you didn't know existed. You'll be scared. And no matter how many books on parenting you read, it's going to feel like you have no idea what you're doing."

"Sometimes, I feel that way now. Other times, I wonder if I should try my hand at designing maternity wear." I waved it away. "I'm probably just getting a swollen head. I heard that big people want to get married in a copy of my gown, and it's stroking my ego."

"If you want to design maternity clothes for yourself, go ahead. You only need to worry about pleasing yourself."

I smiled. "Thanks, Allie. I know this past year can't have been easy on you."

"It's been harder for you, Staci. And you've held up better than I would have."

"But I will warn you of one thing: I know you never wanted me to call you Mom, even though that's who you've been to me since we met. But this baby is calling you Grandma. No arguments."
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: Allie Calls

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
"And how are we today?" Nurse Becky asked me.

"I've gone up a cup size," I replied. "And my clothes still fit, but they feel a little snug in the waist."

"Sounds like you're spot on for your third month," she said. "How's your morning sickness?"

"I'm managing it with ginger snaps, but I'm still looking forward to not having it anymore."

"Both are common. Now, you're probably wondering why I asked you to come in with a full bladder?"

"You could say that," I replied.

"At home," Jesse added, "she used more colorful language."

"Well, I had a very good reason. Excuse me." She stepped outside.

I turned to Jesse. "Whatever she left to get had better bring tears to my eyes, or I'm bringing tears to hers."

She returned a short time later, pushing... an ultrasound machine. "Bit by bit," she said, "we're getting the conveniences."

I squeezed Jesse's hand.

"Now," she said, "the bad news is, the gel is still cold." She then proved it by smearing it all over my tummy.

Next, she helped us to listen to our baby's heartbeat.

Then, she ran the wand over my womb, until... "There we go."

I let out an audible gasp, as tears flowed from my eyes.

Our baby. The little person Jesse and I made three months ago.

"I can print up some hard copies so you can show folks in the village," she said. "And, if you'll give me the contact information, I can send the pictures to your big families."

She could have asked for anything this side of our firstborn, and we would have given it to her.

Then, she toweled the gel off of me, and said the most blessed sentence I had ever heard: "Now you can go pee."
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: My Third Month

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
Our friends loved looking at the ultrasound, with the girls especially getting a kick out of it. A few of the couples even started discussing their own families. This was mostly people in their 20s, as opposed to the former camp counselors.

I even showed it to Mira, who acted the most motherly I'd seen from her since I was a child: she hugged me, and gave me a kiss on the forehead. "I'm happy for you, Staci," she said. "I know you'll be a wonderful mother."

"Staci?"

I looked up. Allie and Libby had both come for a visit. To my surprise, it was Allie who impulsively scooped me up and brought me in for a hug. "Easy on the sudden movements," I called out. "It's not just me, remember?"

"Sorry," she said. "As soon as I saw the ultrasound, I wanted to do that. I guess I forgot how that would feel to you. Say hi to Libby?"

"Of course."

Allie gently lowered me to Libby's level. "Hi, Staci," she said, and gave me a gentle hug. The kiss that followed, however, was not as gentle, and was wet and sloppy.

Allie gave me a tissue to dry myself off with. "How does being an auntie in a few months sound?" I asked her. "Are you excited?"

"Yup," she said. "My friends are jealous, 'cause I'm sisters with the TV lady."

It was touching to think that, after shrinking so small, kids just thought of me as "the TV lady." Or maybe it was just the hormones. Whatever, it brought tears to my eyes.

"This calls for a celebration," Allie said. "What would you like to do?"

"Go to Grey Line," I answered. "Let's see if she's got clothes my size, but a little more roomy in the waist."
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: Reactions

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
"Well, this is unexpected," Allie said.

"What is?" I asked from within her purse.

"Grey Line's busy today. Should we come back another time?"

"Tempting," I replied, "but one thing I remember from when you were carrying Libby is how fast she seemed to grow."

"When was that?" Libby asked.

"Before you were born, Lib. I'll explain later."

"Or maybe we can show her."

Before I could ask Allie what she meant by that, I heard Mrs. Grey's voice. "Good to see you again, Allie," she said. "To what do I owe the pleasure?"

"Clothes shopping," Allie replied, tapping the purse I was in.

"Of course. I figured you'd be coming in soon. What timing, huh? Let's get you in the back room."

Once we were in the back room, Allie let me out of her purse. "What's going on?" I asked. "Why so busy?"

"Our new line of clothes and accessories," Mrs. Grey explained. "Maternity clothes for dolls. It's already become our second most popular seller, right after a certain wedding gown."

"Well, I'm not quite ready for that," I replied. "But I do need something with a little more give in the midsection."

"Of course you do. Let's try on some things, shall we?"

My desire for clothes that fit was somewhere between hope and expectation. As ever for as long as I'd known her, though, Mrs. Grey did not disappoint. "And I'll let you in on a secret," she said. "When you're just puttering around the house, you can wear one of Jesse's shirts. While you're here, would you like to try on what's just ahead for you?"

"Might as well. As I was telling Allie, I know from before Libby was born how fast babies grow when you're pregnant."

Mrs. Grey nodded, and handed me an odd-shaped pillow with straps on it. "Half the secret for our popularity," she said. "From the outside, it looks just like a baby bump. So you'll know how you'll look in maternity wear."

I certainly did. It started me crying all over again, the way so many things did now that I was having a baby. Once or twice, Jesse had jokingly asked if I wanted to see something sappy. You know, the kind of movie that would be guaranteed to bring on the waterworks.

Finally, satisfied that I had enough to wear for a few weeks, I charged my purchases, and Allie picked up some things for Libby.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: Grey Line's New Line

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
Once I was back home, I changed into my new clothes, then went out into the village to show them off.

"Looking good as ever, Staci," Taylor said. "It's unfair that a pregnant woman looks that good."

"Well, I can't take all the credit," I replied. "I didn't design this outfit, I just put it together. When you have a baby on the way, you'll look just as good."

"Well, that won't be for a while, girlfriend. We're in no hurry to have children."

"Neither were Jesse and I. This baby will come when it comes, and we're happy to have it."

While we were talking, Holly ran up to us. "Did you guys hear the news? The governor's daughter is shrinking!"

"What?" I asked. "Mr. Grey didn't tell me anything about any new Nymph fragments."

"That's the kicker!" Holly said. "She's got no connection to Nymph at all!"

No connection to Nymph, and she's shrinking anyway? I had to learn more. I ran back home and pulled up the story on my phone/TV.

"Surprising news from the Governor's Mansion, as Governor Eric Masterson has confirmed that his teenage daughter, Rachel, is shrinking. The reason for this is a mystery, as Ms. Masterson has not been exposed to any fragments of the Nymph comet, unlike previous shrinking cases. Mr. Masterson has asked that his daughter's privacy be respected."

The phone rang.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: Back in the Village

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
Seeing it was Mr Grey, I answered on the second ring. "Staci, I leaving it to your good judgement to tell or not to tell the rest of the village." Serious, he said. "However, this conversation does not reach the camera crew or the public at large."

"This is bad, isn't it...?" Wincing, I asked.

Mr Grey nodded. "This is not an isolated incident, Staci." Gravely, he said. "I am getting reports from all over the world of people shrinking, one dozen total, with Lord knows how many to follow."

"Are we expecting more guests?" Worried, I asked.

"These people are of the super rich." Serious, Mr Grey replied. "Speculations from ransom for an antidote to terrorist attacks on rich families are flying like wildfire among these families, and I have been asked to help them."

"Why you?" Curious, I asked.

"The Grey Line is on the foremost edge of shrinking technology, to accommodate the village and its people." Simply, Mr Grey replied. "The Madurodam Leprechaun Institute is second in that research."

"Have you found a way to reverse the shrinking process?" Surprised, I asked.

"Unfortunately, once one stops shrinking, the result is permanent." Sadly, Mr Grey said. "Only we do not know what is causing this, so I cannot even begin to speculate."

"What do you want me to do?" Curious, I asked.

"Governor Eric Masterson has asked that you talk to his daughter, Rachel, and perhaps discover what is causing her to shrink, before it is too late."

"How tall is she now?" sighing, I asked.

Mr Grey frowned and replied...
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: A call of Duty

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
"She's down to five feet tall," Mr. Grey said. "That's six inches shorter than she was a week ago."

"Sounds like I'm on familiar territory," I said. "Anything else?"

"Your father and stepmother have been invited to the Governor's Mansion, to advise on what Rachel will need as she shrinks. They've pulled her out of college, so you'll all be going together."

"Alright. I'll leave a note for Jesse, then put the word out in the village to keep this off the cameras. I'll keep you posted on what I learn."

"I knew I could count on you, Staci. Goodbye for now."

******************************


With all the friends I've made since the village opened, it was no trouble getting the word out not to discuss any rumors of shrinking in front of the cameras. I'm sure that the whole village knew about it by the time Dad, Allie, and Libby came to pick me up.

Instead of our car, we got into a limousine for our ride to the mansion. Allie had her hands full trying to get Libby under control.

Once we were in the mansion, Allie handed the purse I was in to the governor's wife. Governor Masterson asked the family to go with him, while Mrs. Masterson carried me to what had to be Rachel's bedroom.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: Five feet.

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
Mrs. Masterson knocked on the door. "Rachel, honey," she said, "someone's here to see you."

"Tell them to go away," Rachel replied.

"We asked her to come, Rachel. She knows what you're going through."

The door opened. "Nobody knows what I'm going through."

"I might be able to take a rough guess," I called from inside the purse.

Rachel paused. "That sounds like a person in there."

I poked my upper half out of the purse. "Hi. My name's Staci. You're Rachel, I take it?"

Rachel's eyes nearly popped out of her head. "You're real? I thought it was special effects."

"I'm as real as you are. Can I come in? This purse is okay for getting from Point A to Point B, but you don't want to hang out in it."

Rachel took the purse into her bedroom, then let me out on a dresser.

I took a look around. Rachel's things were more expensive than my things from before I shrank, but they were basically the same.

As for Rachel herself, she was wearing a floral print dress, with a ring on a chain around her neck. Also, she'd been crying. "I like your dress," I said.

She played with it. "I'm a T-shirt and jeans girl, really," she said. "But one-piece dresses stay on me longer. I don't know what I'll do when I'm too small for this."

"My stepmom's a packrat," I said. "She hung on to a lot of my clothes when I grew up, which came in handy when I went the other way. Grey Line can help you out starting when you're the size of a five-year-old."

She looked at me with disbelief. "How can you be so blase about this?"

I shrugged. "My best friends shrank along with me, so I knew I wasn't going through it alone. And there's my life since then. If I hadn't shrunk, I would be Skyping with Jesse all the time. Instead, we're married, and I'm going to have a baby."
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: Rachel Masterson

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
"How did you get here?" Rachel asked. "Besides the purse."

"Your folks invited my folks to come," I explained. "If we can't turn this around, they want to know how to preserve as much of your independence as possible. That's what the village is all about."

"Can you tell me what's causing this?"

I shook my head. "I'm a fashion designer, not a physicist." I decided to change the subject. "That ring around your neck. What's his name?"

She pulled it out by the chain. "It's mine. Daddy bought it for me, six weeks ago. Before it got too big for me, I never took it off, except for bedtime and the shower. Oh, and when I cleaned it. Want to see it?" She moved her ring toward me, to give me a better look.

And something pushed me backward. Hard. It knocked me off my feet.

Rachel noticed it, too. "Are you okay? What was that?"

"I don't know," I replied, standing back up. "If I didn't know better, I'd swear you just punched me."

She looked at her ring. "Did it do that?"

"Sure seems like it. What can you tell me about it?"

She examined the ring. "It's a new gemstone. I can't pronounce the name. When I wore it, I felt stronger, more energetic. It couldn't be the ring, could it? I mean, I wore it long before I started shrinking."

"I don't know. You said you cleaned it? When was that?"

She shrugged. "Sometime last week." Her eyes widened. "Right before I started shrinking. Did the cleaning solution do it?"

She brought the bottle of cleaning solution up to me. "It's definitely a piece of the puzzle. It's not pushing me back, but I feel like I don't want to get too close. May I use your phone?"

She cleared the repellent objects away, then put her phone in front of me. I dialed Mr. Grey.

He answered on the second ring. "Hello? Who is this?"

"It's Staci, Mr. Grey. I'm here with Rachel Masterson. I think we might have found a clue." I described the ring, the cleaning solution, and my reactions to both.

"It's too much to be coincidental," he said. "Alert the governor to expect my team. We'll examine the ring under secure conditions, then we'll see if we can help Rachel."

"Help me?" Rachel asked. "Like how?"

"I don't want to get your hopes up too much before we know for sure," Mr. Grey said. "But we just might be able to bring you up to or near your original height. We'll know for certain later. Goodbye for now." He hung up.

Rachel turned to me. "Did he say he could restore my size?"

"He said he would try," I cautioned. "But we might have found what's causing the shrinking, and we can warn others before it happens to them. Go tell your folks he's coming."
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: A Clue

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
Grey Line agents were at the Governor's Mansion half an hour after my call to Mr. Grey ended. They collected the ring and the cleaning solution, then took Rachel into a car, along with her parents and, at her insistence, me. Dad and Allie had to follow in the limo.

For all of Rachel's asking, I wasn't allowed to be with her as they examined her. Instead, I waited with Mr. Grey for the results.

We only had to wait half an hour for some of the results. "The gemstone's name is Gleaming Arguclasite. We've got a sample, if you're willing to test it."

I nodded, and he produced the stone. "Commercially, it's called Halostone. Rachel isn't the only one who reported a stimulant effect. How does it make you feel?"

"The same as the cleaning solution: I want to get away, but I'm not being pushed like with Rachel's ring."

Mr. Grey nodded. "It's not one or the other, but it's both. Any other cleaning solution, and the ring's effect wouldn't change. Any other gemstone, and it would just clean. But use this solution on this stone, and it releases the same radiation as Nymph."

"So that's why Rachel is shrinking," I said. "But why did it push me?"

"Because you've already shrunk. You're immune to the shrinking effect, and now it repels you."

"Okay. So you can alert the others who are shrinking, they can destroy their Halostone jewelry that's been touched by the cleaning solution. How's it looking for Rachel?"

"We can try something. For now, we'll get the word out."

*****************************


We wound up spending the night at the Grey Line facility. The next morning, Mr. Grey received messages from around the world. "It seems that some of those now shrinking made the connection between the gemstone and their shrinking already. However, they appear to have concluded that the jewels are cursed, and they gave them away, increasing the number of shrinking cases."

"How typical," I said, "thinking only of themselves. What's the good word on Rachel?"
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: At the Grey Line Facility

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
Mr. Grey sighed. "Unfortunately, this gemstone was in its purest form." Softly, he explained. "As such, its radiation was three times more potent than the Nymph comet fragment, that had other metals mixed in."

"So... she's still shrinking?" Sadly, I asked.

Mr Grey gave a silent nod. "She will be your size by the end of the week." Frowning, he said. "She... is taking it badly." He shook his head. "Her father is taking it worse, blaming himself for it happening."

"Where did these gemstones come from?" Curious, I asked.

"You remember the people of Madurodam saying the Nymph comet had sisters?" Serious, Mr Grey replied. "Not all of them were the same."

"So someone found a fragment of one of these sisters, and broke it up to sell the pieces as gemstones." Frowning, I said. "Wonderful..."

Mr Grey nodded. "Only we must first deal with damage control, before we have a panic on our hands."

"Any way to reverse Rachel's shrinking?" worried, I asked.

Mr. Grey shook his head. "All we can do is help her adapt to her new reality."

"Are the police looking for the 'cursed' gemstones?"

Mr. Grey nodded. "They are, but it will take time." Serious, he said.

We both stopped talking as a small voice reached us. "Um... Staci..."

I turned to find Rachel looking at us from an open door. She was now...
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: She's Still Shrinking

choices: Rachel Will Stay with Her Parents
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
Rachel was now maybe four and a half feet tall. And we all knew she wouldn't be that big for long. The full-sized people in the facility towered over her already.

"I'm here, Rach," I called out to her.

As she approached, I could tell that the only reason she wasn't crying now was because she was all out of tears. "What's going to happen to me?" she asked me. "What am I going to do?"

"Whatever you want," I replied. "No matter what your size, you're still you. Your parents love you, and your name opens doors."

"Staci,... what's it like in the village?"

"Well, there's cameras everywhere but the can. I like to believe that they get shut off during more... intimate moments."

"They damn well ought to be," Mr. Grey said. "If I find out otherwise, those responsible will be out of their jobs, and I will sue them on behalf of the villagers."

"On the other hand," I continued, "we've got most of the modern conveniences, and we're getting more all the time. For free time, there's a tennis court, a basketball court, a playground for the kids, and a petting zoo. At night, if we don't want to watch TV, there's a movie theater. And there's a community center where we take college courses."

A sad smile touched her face. "To tell you the truth, Staci, I only went to college because Dad said it was expected of me. I don't know if I want to go."

"Alright," I said. "One of my best friends, her first plan for after high school was to walk around. It wasn't until after we started shrinking that she found her calling in veterinary medicine. Maybe you'll find yours the same way."

"I want to be a mother."

"Well, between the village, Madurodam, and the gemstone/cleaner combination, I'm sure you'll have plenty of chances. Take some time, figure out where you want to be."

"I think I know."
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: The size of a child.

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
"Once I stop shrinking," Rachel said, "I'm moving to the village."

"We'll be glad to have you," I replied.

"I've just got two more questions," she said. "Who's in charge there? You?"

"Me? God, I hope not!" I laughed. "I'll let you in on the world's worst-kept secret: Nobody's in charge. No one person is more important than anybody else, and that's how we like it. If I were in charge, people would come to me with their problems, and they'd want to know what I was going to do about them. As it is, people tell me their problems, but they also tell me their joys, and the only question they ask is 'How are you?'"

"Okay, Question 2: Can I get smokes there?"

"Under no circumstances," Mr. Grey said. "Flame doesn't miniaturize, and plastic is flammable."

"What he said," I said.

"Just as well," Rachel said with a sigh, "I've been meaning to quit cigarettes. I heard they stunt your growth."

We all laughed.

"Alright, Rachel," Mr. Grey said, "let's tell your parents about your decision."

She took his hand. "Between the size of your hand and how high I have to reach, I feel like a kid again," she said.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: Rachel Will Join the Village

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
After all of us were home (though the Governor's Mansion wouldn't be Rachel's home for more than a week), the news relayed the whole story: how Rachel would shrink to our size, her plans to join the village and the show. Most importantly, they told a panic-stricken world how and why the shrinking was happening.

"It's two new products working together," the reporter explained. "If you own jewelry that features Gleaming Arguclasite, and clean it with anything other than Halo cleaning solution, there will be no ill effects. If you use Halo on any other gemstone, there will also be no ill effects. But if you clean Arguclasite with Halo, the combination will cause shrinking. There are as yet unconfirmed reports that some of the people who found themselves shrinking decided to give their jewels away, so anyone handling second-hand Arguclasite jewelry should be careful."

The phone rang, so I switched over and answered it. "Yes?"

"The word is out, Staci," Mr. Grey said. "Early reports suggest that people are now taking proper actions to prevent further shrinking."

"Glad to hear it," I said. "Any news on the 'cursed' jewels?"

"We've tracked down a couple of them." He paused. "One was in the States."
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: The News

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
I braced myself for the worst. "Tell me more."

"She's a teenage girl, lives close by," Mr. Grey said. "Her father got her a necklace for her birthday. By nightfall, they noticed what was happening. She's resting now. She was afraid to fall asleep when she came in. Rather, she was afraid of what she'd wake up to find."

"If she's shrinking that fast, I don't blame her," I said. "How close by?"

"As a matter of fact, she lives in the building. Her name's Carrie Matheson."

"Shit."

"What is it?"

"Carrie's the family babysitter. She looked after Libby. And me, once I got too small to take care of things."

"I'm sorry, Staci. This is always difficult, but for it to happen to a family friend,... "

"At least we're taking care of her. And she loves kids, so she won't be hurting for clients. And, in a couple years, she'll even be working for the family again." My phone beeped. "I've got an incoming call. I'll get back to you. Goodbye for now."

I put on the next call. "Hello?"

"Staci, it's Allie. You're not going to believe this, but Carrie's shrinking."

"I just heard it from Mr. Grey. She's resting, Allie, so don't worry. You'll just be looking for a new babysitter, something you would have had to do in a few months, anyway."

"You're sure she'll be okay?"

"You know how many children live here, you tell me."

"Alright, Staci. Thanks for reassuring me."

"You would have done the same. Go break the news to Libby."
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: The Incredible Shrinking Birthday Girl

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
Rachel and Carrie came to the village on the same day. After they had the chance to say hello to everyone, Jesse and I invited them up to the house.

"How do you like the village so far?" Jesse asked.

"I think I'll like it here," Rachel replied.

"It'll take some getting used to," Carrie said. "I forgot that Staci was taller than I was."

"You know each other?" Rachel asked.

"Carrie babysat for most of the families in the building," I explained. "She kept an eye on my half-sister, Libby. And on me, while I was slowly shrinking."

The four of us talked for a while, until the lights went out. "What happened?" Rachel asked.

"Don't panic," called the camera technician. "It's just a power outage. Probably a squirrel fried itself on a transformer. We'll be back up and running in no time."

"Want to move our chat outside?" I asked.

Before anyone could answer, the phone rang. "It's Allie, my stepmom," I said, answering it. "Hello?"

"Staci, Libby fell down wrong and hurt her arm. I think it's broken."

"Oh, no! Where are you?"

"In the park. I've called your father, and he'll be there to pick you guys up. We'll see you at the hospital." With that, she hung up.

We all left the house, and Jesse and I were picked up by Dad.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: Rachel and Carrie

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
"You gave us a scare, sis," I said, as Libby was fitted for a sling.

"It's not my fault," Libby said. "Trevor dared me."

"I don't think it works like that, Libby," Jesse said.

A nurse came in. "Excuse me," she said, then turned to Jesse and me. "May I ask something of you?"

"Like what?"

"We have some sick children here. Nothing contagious, you understand."

I understood. Sick, in this case, was a euphemism for cancer.

"A visit from a couple of celebrities sure would lift their spirits. Would you - "

"We'd love to," Jesse said.

The nurse brought in a bassinet. We got in, and she pushed us.

******************************


The pediatric cancer ward was a study in contrasts. On the one hand, you had kids who were someplace they didn't want to be, and they were making the best they could of it. On the other hand, there was the unspoken truth that some of these kids weren't going to get better.

When Jesse and I poked our heads out of the bassinet, however, none of that seemed to matter. Nor did they care that they were so much bigger than we were. They were kids, and we were people they'd seen on TV.

We answered all of their questions (most were about us having a baby), we posed for pictures. More than that, we cheered them up.

We couldn't cure cancer, but we could, and did, let them forget about it for a while.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: The Hospital

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
"Everything looks on track," Nurse Becky said. "You're right where you ought to be for your fourth month."

"That's good to hear," I said, pulling my top back down over my belly, which now stuck out as far as my boobs.

"Did you want to know if it's a boy or a girl?"

I shook my head. "Jesse and I want to be surprised."

She nodded. "Now, if you were big, your OB/GYN would talk to you about amniocentesis. But we can't do that for you. Even if a needle could get through your skin, you don't have enough amniotic fluid to run a test. So, we'll just have to hope for the best."

"I'm not worried."

"Atta girl. So, what are your plans?"

"Oh,... nothing much."

Becky nodded, then hit the kill switch. It was our code for when I didn't want what I had to say to make it on the tape. "Tell me."

"We've been invited to Madurodam. Jesse, me, and our best friends."

"What's the occasion?"

"Two of them: It's the first anniversary of the camping trip that led to our shrinking, and it's the anniversary of the shrinking that led to the building of Madurodam."

"Sounds like fun. How are you getting there?"

"The Greys are taking a trip. Once they drop us off, it'll be just the two of them."

"Have a good time."

"Now that I've discovered ginger snaps, me having a good time is guaranteed."
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: One Year

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
The trans-Atlantic flight was uneventful, at least for me. Quinn discovered that she gets sick on airplanes, so she lay curled up in Mrs. Grey's bag. I asked the Greys to remind me to share my ginger snaps with her for the return flight. During my pregnancy, I discovered, my memory wasn't always reliable.

On our arrival at Madurodam, we were all welcomed, with my friends from the previous trip congratulating me again, now that I was obviously pregnant. After the third time I was asked about names, I asked Jesse to remind me to ask Mr. Grey to shrink me some baby name books, to join the pregnancy books in our study.

When the park closed for the night, we all took a tour of the city. "It's breathtaking," Taylor said of one replica of an old building in particular.

"Not as much as you," Dave said.

Taylor turned to brush off his compliment, only to gasp as Dave got down on one knee.

"Taylor Brown, will you marry me?"

Taylor whispered something none of us could hear. When she was able to breathe again, she said, "Yes."

We all congratulated the happy couple, with Tommy adding a lighthearted "Way to put the pressure on me, dude."
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: Back to Madurodam

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
The next day was the anniversary celebration. We were seated at the main table, which featured a lectern for after-dinner speeches. A veritable feast was set before us (a big treat for those of us who were eating for two), and we all had a good time.

Madurodam's honorary mayor stepped to the lectern. "Welcome, one and all, to our celebration," he said, "and a special welcome to our friends from America, for joining us this year."

We received a polite round of applause.

"This is not only the anniversary of the event that led to the building of Madurodam," he continued. "By an extraordinary coincidence, it is the first anniversary of when our friends' story began. Perhaps one of them would like to share their tale with us?"

The thunderous applause that followed told me that the residents would like to hear it, and Jesse's elbow told me that I was expected to do the honors. I got up and went to the lectern. "I'll do the best I can," I said. "I beg your indulgence if pregnancy brain means I falter a bit here and there.

"That night wasn't really when our story began. We grew up in the same apartment building, and we've known each other our whole lives. But it looked like our different dreams were going to pull us in different directions, and we planned the camping trip as a last hurrah for our little group. We'd gone to... where did we go?"

Pause for laughter, and for Jesse to remind me.

"Mystic Pines. We'd gone to Mystic Pines plenty of times before, so it seemed like the perfect spot. We knew the way, we knew the trails: It seemed like it held no surprises for us.

"Well, maybe the campgrounds held no surprises, but the same couldn't be said for the skies above. We'd set up camp, and we were celebrating around the campfire, when a fragment of a certain comet came crashing down.

"When we recovered from the shock, we called off our camping trip and went home. But the damage was done: three days later, we realized that we were shrinking.

"I've come to realize that what brought us there that night was, ultimately, what helped us to deal with what happened to us: No matter how strange it was to get smaller every day, no matter how frustrating it was to have more and more things out of our reach, we knew there were... " I paused to count, which got more laughter and applause. "We each knew there were five others dealing with the exact same thing. We weren't alone: we were together.

"And we stayed together. With the village, we found a way to follow our dreams while staying together. And some of us have become even closer. Just look at me, and you can see how close Jesse and I are.

"When I go anywhere, people ask me, 'If you had it to do over again, would you change your mind about going on that camping trip?' I can tell you for certain: I wouldn't change a thing."

That got a standing ovation, and I'm sure the tourists were wondering what the noise was, and what it meant.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: The Next Day

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
Sure enough, the room became darker, as a little girl of about four or five peered in at us. The residents, who had been so happy just a moment before, were now terrified at the prospect of the girl tearing the building apart to get at the little people she saw inside.

I kept my cool. "Hello, young one," I called to her. "Please don't tell anyone out there that we're in here. Alright?"

The girl nodded. "I won't tell. My name is Floortje. You will tell Sinterklass, ja?"

Sinterklass? Oh, right, Santa Claus. She thought we were elves. "I will make sure he knows the very next time I see him. Be good, now."

The girl nodded and left.

As the room settled down again, the mayor said, "That was quick thinking on your part. I was sure we were doomed."

"It was nothing," I said. "I have a six-year-old half-sister."

******************************


Later, the mayor said, "Thank you again for visiting us for this day. Perhaps, if we can find a way, some of us will go to visit you and your village."

"You are more than welcome, Mr. Mayor."

"I just thought of something," Jesse said. "We've all been shrunk by fragments of one comet or another. Do you think there could be more Madurodams out there?"

"Nothing quite like our beautiful city," he replied. "But I'm sure that there are other communities of people made small by such fragments. But, without a city like ours to draw attention, there is no way to tell how they would react to visitors. Come, let us watch the fireworks."

The sky was lit up as fireworks were shot off to celebrate Madurodam's anniversary. Interestingly, they did not appear bigger or louder than they would have had we been full size. Perhaps a physicist could explain it.

No physicist was needed to explain what happened beneath the fireworks, though, as Tommy proposed to Quinn. Finally, she accepted.
1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.title: That Night

1111111111111113111111111211111311111112.content:
The flight home was comfortable, and I remembered to buy some ginger snaps while in Madurodam for Quinn. Upon returning to the village, we were all in good spirits, but none of us expected to find the entire summer camp waiting for us. Hannah was the first to run up to us, with Fozzie following, his tail happily wagging. "We missed you!" Smiling, Hannah said. "Mommy is showing off my baby sister, Ina."

That's right, Grace was pregnant the last time we had seen her. "We missed you too, squirt." Smiling back, I said. "What brings all of you to the village?"

"Mr Grey told us that Growing Up in Miniature is doing really well." Calmly, Hannah replied. "He said we all earned a vacation."

"You're taking a vacation here in the village?" Curious, I asked.

"Not quite." Startling me, Mr Grey said. "I've set up a summer camp environment in another apartment in this building." He chuckled. "It was a nightmare to set up the contract for the show, but the gamble paid off."

"I'm guessing it's the off-season for the show." Calmly, I said.

Mr Grey nodded. "Long story short, there are endless limitations, due to federal law and complicated contracts with minors, but the money pouring in from the show makes it well worth it." Calmly, he said. "The kids get well paid, and their parents get peace of mind, knowing their kids are safe."

"Does this mean we are getting a vacation, too?" Hopefully, I asked.

Again, Mr. Grey nodded. "You are all invited, but no one is saying you have to go." Serious, he replied. "Not all of the kids from the summer camp came, due to their parents wanting more time with them."

"Will any of the summer camp be filmed?" curious, Jessie asked.
